column1: ---split---2.0---split---http://www.bbc.com/culture/story/20190212-come-from-away-why-we-need-the-911-musical---split---As the Broadway hit opens in London
column2: Rebecca Laurence recalls the real story of those stranded in Canada on 11 September 2001. Do you remember where you were on 11 September 2001? Chances are that if you were alive and old enough to recall it
column3: you will. Like thousands of others
column4: I was mid-air
column5: crossing the Atlantic bound for North America. My dad and I were headed from the UK to my grandfather’s funeral in Florida (or so we thought). But following the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon that morning
column6: US airspace was shut; every plane in the air had to be diverted and grounded immediately
column7: including ours. Hundreds of aircraft carrying thousands of bewildered passengers landed on the easternmost edges of the continent
column8: with scarce advance warning. The people on the ground frantically tried to figure out what to do with us. More like this: – The Welsh reporter who exposed Stalin – The most important man in 200 years – Why the Danish love Rita The tragic events of 11 September and the chaos that followed may seem the unlikeliest of subjects for feel-good entertainment. But
column9: Come From Away
column10: dubbed ‘the 9/11 musical’
column11: is the surprise Broadway hit – now open in London – that’s found a way. It’s the brainchild of husband-and-wife-team David Hein and Irene Sankoff
column12: Canadian musical-theatre-makers who were living in New York City in 2001. With a rousing live folk band and foot-stamping songs – Come From Away focuses on the quiet heroism and kindness of the inhabitants of one tiny town in Canada. The population of Gander
column13: Newfoundland
column14: which was around 9
column16: nearly doubled as an estimated 38 airplanes holding over 6
column17: 500 people landed. Its huge airport – as a major refuelling stop – was once the largest in the world
column18: but the town had just 500 hotel rooms.   The musical began to take shape after Irene and David spent several weeks in Gander in 2011
column19: attending a 10-year reunion of the ‘come from aways’ (also known as the ‘plane people’ in local parlance). They were inspired by the stories of hospitality they heard and the deep bonds that had been formed in those few days. They conducted hundreds of hours’ worth of interviews with Gander natives and their visitors before condensing these conversations into a 100-minute play with just 12 actors. We often call it a ‘9/12’ story – David Hein “Everyone on stage is to some degree a composite of multiple people
column20: ” David Hein tells BBC Culture. “In that way we wanted to represent everyone who had either helped people or were being helped on that day. “We weren’t trying to write a 9/11 story
column21: ” he continues. “We often call it a ‘9/12’ story. We wanted to tell the story of what happened in Newfoundland. It’s not about the tragedy; it’s about how this small community responded to the tragedy.” Both the drama and the humour in Come From Away are borne out of these unique circumstances: the desperate ‘plane people’ trapped on board for up to 30 hours with no connection to the outside world; the locals who scrambled to clothe and feed the thousands
column22: who came from 95 countries. A couple
column23: Nick and Diane
column24: meet and fall in love; another separates. Beverley Bass
column25: American Airlines’ first female captain
column26: is a central figure
column27: as is Bonnie Harris
column28: the animal carer who took charge of a menagerie of 19 – including a pregnant Bonobo chimpanzee. It’s all suffused with Gander’s gentle idiosyncrasies and unique customs
column29: Irish/Newfoundlander dialect and an eccentric ‘screech’ indoctrination ceremony (spoiler: it involves kissing a cod).   Amid the jollity and musical numbers there are sudden touches of pathos: a mother learns her NYC firefighter son is lost; an Egyptian Muslim chef wants to help cook but is treated with suspicion; the moment the ‘plane people’ – trapped on board for 15
column31: 30 hours before disembarking – first see the images of the World Trade Center attacks. Kindness and catharsis Not far beyond Newfoundland is Halifax
column32: Nova Scotia
column33: where our plane and dozens of others landed. Housed four to a room in a naval base
column34: we were fed in the canteen and slept on mattresses on the floor for several days while airspace was closed. Having missed my grandfather’s funeral and with nothing to do
column35: we whiled away the hours by chatting with our roommates
column36: a retired English couple and other fellow plane people; going on a whale-watching tour – anything to distract us from those searing images that played over and over on the television. Considering the sadness and sensitivity around 9/11
column37: even several years later
column38: were Irene and David concerned with how people would respond to the play? Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau attended a performance and invited Ivanka Trump “I frankly never thought that the show would make it to the US because of the material
column39: ” Irene confesses. “We were definitely worried. I remember the first audience in the States
column40: just sinking in my seat
column41: thinking
column42: ‘whose idea was this?’” But they needn’t have worried – the response to Come From Away has been wholly positive
column43: even jubilant. In 2017
column44: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau attended a performance on Broadway and invited Ivanka Trump to watch it with him. The play was nominated for seven Tonys and a Grammy; it has had a run in Dublin
column45: Ireland
column46: and in addition to opening in London
column47: is touring North America
column48: and opens in Melbourne
column49: Australia later this year. At the performance I attended in London earlier this month
column50: it got a standing ovation.   And although people may come to the ‘9/11 musical’ expecting to shed a few tears
column51: David suggests that when they do it’s not always for the reasons they might expect. “These days we’re so used to our news feeds being filled with divisive anger and fearmongering
column52: things that make us turn into an ‘us and them society
column53: ’” he says. “To see something where people were able to come together despite their differences and to remember that in times of crisis that’s what we do
column54: that’s what we can do
column55: I think that’s why people cry” he says. “It reminds us that we can be good.” And as another ‘come from away’ – albeit one who remembers being welcomed and cared for in a different Canadian town – I can attest that not only is the play true
column56: it’s irresistible. Irene and David like to quote the Mayor of Gander
column57: Claude Elliott
column58: who didn’t go home for five days after 9/11. “We started off with 7000 strangers
column59: ” he said
column60: “but we finished with 7000 family members.” Ultimately it’s this warmth and humanity to which audiences respond. “Almost without thinking about it they welcomed people into the towns
column61: ” David says. “It’s such an important thing for people to hear right now.” Come From Away opens in London on 18 February
column62: is touring North America and opens in Melbourne
column63: Australia in July 2019. If you would like to comment on this story or anything else you have seen on BBC Culture
column64: head over to our Facebook page or message us on Twitter. And if you liked this story
column65: sign up for the weekly bbc.com features newsletter
column66: called “If You Only Read 6 Things This Week”. A handpicked selection of stories from BBC Future

column1: ---split---2.0---split---https://www.bbc.com/news/business-47248644---split---Share this with Email Facebook Messenger Messenger Twitter Pinterest WhatsApp LinkedIn Copy this link These are external links and will open in a new window Trade talks between the US and China have broken up without a deal
column2: with the US warning that "very difficult issues" remain unresolved. The talks in China this week were aimed at securing a new deal before further US tariffs are imposed on 1 March. China said negotiations would now continue in the US next week. "We feel that we have to make headway on some very
column3: very important and very difficult issues
column4: said top US trade negotiator Robert Lighthizer. However, he said he was hopeful" of progress. President Xi Jinping said he hoped talks next week would "continue to work hard to promote a mutually beneficial and win-win agreement." The two countries have been locked in an escalating trade war
column5: imposing duties on billions of dollars worth of one another's goods. In December
column6: both countries agreed to halt new tariffs for 90 days to allow for talks. The US has said it will increase tariff rates on $200bn worth of Chinese imports from 10% to 25% if the two sides do not strike a deal by 1 March. But President Trump recently hinted that this deadline could be extended if they are making good progress in negotiations with China. By Andrew Walker
column7: BBC World Service economics correspondent It's a relatively optimistic tone from officials on both sides and at very senior levels too: President Xi himself for China and two US Cabinet level figures
column8: in the shape of the Treasury Secretary and the US Trade Representative. Talks to continue in Washington next week. So is (trade) peace imminent? That would be a rash assumption to make. We have had warm words before and the big ask from the US side is difficult for China. The next stage in China's economic development really does need technology and they will not easily agree to give up the practice of expecting foreign investors to share theirs. That said
column9: a willingness to continue talking as soon as next week
column10: does suggest some reason for hope. Washington is pressing Beijing to make changes to its economic policies
column11: which it says unfairly favour domestic companies through subsidies and other support. The US has also accused the government of supporting technology theft as part of its broader development strategy. It wants to bring down its large trade deficit with the Asian powerhouse and wants China to buy more US goods. China has proposed to increase purchases of US goods
column12: such as semiconductors and soybeans
column13: but is unlikely to let up on its economic development model
column14: according to media reports. There is also a sense among some in China that the US is using the trade war to contain its rise
column15: as the two superpowers jostle for global leadership. Countries elsewhere have also become wary of China's rise. Several governments have blocked telecoms companies from using equipment made by Huawei
column16: the Chinese telecoms giant
column17: in next-generation 5G mobile networks due to security concerns. The US has imposed tariffs on $250bn worth of Chinese goods
column18: and China has retaliated by imposing duties on $110bn of US products. Mr Trump has also threatened further tariffs on an additional $267bn worth of Chinese products - which would see virtually all of Chinese imports into the US become subject to these tariffs. column1: ---split---2.0---split---https://www.nbcnews.com/news/military/green-beret-charged-murder-says-he-killed-afghan-man-book-n972071---split---A Green Beret accused of murdering an unarmed Afghan man described new details about why he set up an ambush that led to his fatally shooting the alleged Taliban bombmaker and offered other new details about developments that led to the charge he now faces. Maj. Mathew Golsteyn
column2: speaking to "NBC Nightly News" anchor Lester Holt in an interview set to air Friday night
column3: said U.S. forces found the man with bomb components after two Marines were killed in Marjah
column4: Afghanistan
column5: in 2010. The man was taken into custody
column6: but Golsteyn said he later directed his release. Watch this story tonight on “NBC Nightly News With Lester Holt" at 6:30 p.m. ET / 5:30 p.m. CT. After releasing the man
column7: Golsteyn told Holt: "I set an ambush." "You've had a lot of time to play this over in your mind. Is there anything that you regret
column8: any decision that you wish you had not made?" Holt asked. "Not at all
column9: Golsteyn said. The Army alleges that Golsteyn murdered the suspected bomb maker when he was deployed in Helmand Province in 2010. Golsteyn first admitted to killing the Afghan man during a CIA job interview in 2011. The Army Criminal Investigation Command (CID) launched an investigation into the killing, but did not charge him due to a lack of physical evidence, according to army officials. Instead, Golsteyn was issued a formal letter of reprimand and stripped of his Silver Star, the military's third highest award for valor, and Special Forces patch. In 2016, Golsteyn appeared on FOX News and admitted to killing the Afghan man. The interview brought new attention to the case. Golsteyn was charged with premeditated murder in December. President Donald Trump at the time tweeted that he would review the case, referring to Golsteyn as a U.S. military hero." In his interview with Holt
column10: Golsteyn said he hasn't heard from Trump but was heartened by his comment. While he and his wife
column11: Julie
column12: would welcome a pardon
column13: he said he's not holding out for one. "It would be amazing
column14: Golsteyn said. We would welcome it. It would put finality to this for us. But we are preparing to take the Army head on." Golsteyn said there was no doubt in his mind the Afghan man was a bomb maker and setting an ambush to engage him if he returned to join the Taliban fighters was in line with the rules of engagement on the battlefield. The charges made against him by Army investigators could be applied to many other U.S. troops
column15: he said
column16: given the actions he took. "What they have endeavored to do is to describe what I would say is a fairly routine combat action as murder
column17: Golsteyn said. Anyone who's participated in the global war on terror over the last 15 years is likely subject to be accused of murder under this rubric." The fighting in Marjah in early 2010 was so fierce that civilians had largely vacated the area
column18: Golsteyn said. He described the Afghan man as a bomb maker "going back to his combat unit" and "a member of a declared hostile force." He said he staged the ambush only to intercept the Afghan man if he walked in the direction toward a base of Taliban fighters
column19: not if he'd walked in a different direction. "He could've gone any direction in Marjah. And if he went back to rejoin his unit that's when he met me in an ambush. Had he gone any other direction we don't meet
column20: Golsteyn said. He declined to say whether he conducted the ambush alone. He said he believes the Afghan man saw him, but that the two did not exchange any words. No one ordered him to do it, he said, because he had the authority to stage the ambush and his actions were consistent with the rules of engagement. Our standing rules of engagement
column21: not just say I can make that engagement
column22: he said, they order me to make that engagement." His immediate commander
column23: he said
column24: has testified "that had I not made that decision he would've fired me." NBC News was not present at the board of inquiry when Golsteyn's commander allegedly made the comment and could not confirm. After the ambush Golsteyn said he went back to his base. He wouldn't discuss his disposal of the body
column25: which was burned. He did say burning bodies was not uncommon given the area was clear of civilians who would claim them
column26: and there were concerns about battlefield hygiene and the Taliban booby trapping them with explosives. Golsteyn said he didn't tell anyone back at the base at the time
column27: not because he was trying to conceal his actions
column28: but because it was something that didn't stand out as extraordinary given the battles American forces were in on a daily basis. He said it was not unusual for U.S. troops to set ambushes and described the incident as "not an extraordinary moment in a situation where every day was extraordinary." "We were in combat from sun up to sun down
column29: he said. We were in these types of engagements all day. Sometimes with just a smoke or with people. We didn't come back and go
column30: "Hey
column31: I was out there and got shot at today or shot the — …That wasn't the thing of what we talked about." A spokesman for U.S. Special Operations Command
column32: Lt. Col. Loren Bymer
column33: noted that Golsteyn has waived his right to a preliminary hearing in military court. "Since recalled to active duty
column34: Maj. Golsteyn has been afforded the respect his rank commands and received the same privileges as all soldiers assigned to United States Army Special Operations Command
column35: Bymer added. The date of next step in MAJ Golsteyn's case is undetermined at this time. As an active law enforcement matter
column36: it would be inappropriate to comment further on the case." The case has taken a toll on Golsteyn and his wife
column37: Julie. Julie Golsteyn said it has so affected her views of the Army that she would not allow her infant son serving in the military. "Would you wanna see your son join the military?" "I would be open to it
column38: Golsteyn said. But his wife quickly chimed in: Absolutely not." "Over my dead body
column39: she said, which makes me very sad and that breaks my heart to say." Carol E. Lee is a national political reporter for NBC News. Courtney Kube is a national security and military reporter for NBC News. © 2019 NBC UNIVERSAL

column3: Eric Reid and the NFL agreed to settle on Friday
column4: but the case won’t truly be resolved until Kaepernick is back on the field. USA TODAY Sports Colin Kaepernick and Eric Reid have settled their respective collusion grievances against the NFL. Attorney Mark Geragos
column5: who has represented the two players in the matter
column6: and the NFL each confirmed the confidential agreement in a joint statement Friday afternoon. "For the past several months
column7: counsel for Mr. Kaepernick and Mr. Reid have engaged in an ongoing dialogue with representatives of the NFL
column8: Geragos and the NFL said in the statement. As a result of those discussions
column9: the parties have decided to resolve the pending grievances. The resolution of this matter is subject to a confidentiality agreement so there will be no further comment by any party." Financial terms of the settlements were not disclosed. Yahoo! Sports reported a final hearing on the collusion grievances had been scheduled for this month. pic.twitter.com/5sdcGSuwvW The NFL Players Association said in a statement that it is not aware of the details of the settlements but supported the players' decision. "We continuously supported Colin and Eric from the start of their protests
column10: participated with their lawyers throughout their legal proceedings and were prepared to participate in the upcoming trial in pursuit of both truth and justice for what believe the NFL and its clubs did to them
column11: the union said in the statement. We are glad that Eric has earned a job and a new contract and we continue to hope that Colin gets his opportunity as well." Kaepernick
column12: who was the first NFL player to kneel during the national anthem as a means of protesting police brutality and racial inequality
column13: filed his grievance against the NFL in October 2017 under the league's collective bargaining agreement. Reid
column14: Kaepernick's former teammate
column15: filed a similar grievance in May. Opinion: Colin Kaepernick proves to be a winner again in settlement with NFL The players alleged that NFL owners had colluded to keep them out of the league because of their protests
column16: which sent ripples across the league during the 2016 and 2017 seasons — particularly after President Donald Trump used an expletive at a rally to describe protesting players
column17: and blasted the NFL for allowing the protests in the first place. A decision on the case was initially expected in the first half of 2019
column18: but a settlement looked to be the eventual outcome after a decision handed down August. That’s when Stephen Burbank
column19: the arbitrator who handled the case
column20: denied the NFL’s motion for a summary judgment
column21: a maneuver – if granted – would have dismissed the case. Burbank had much of the evidence in the case at that point
column22: which included numerous depositions. NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell
column23: NFL Executive Vice President Troy Vincent and Dallas Cowboys owner Jerry Jones were among those deposed in the case. Geragos even attempted to depose Trump and Vice President Mike Pence
column24: USA TODAY Sports reported in June. Kaepernick remains a free agent
column25: while Reid has since returned to the NFL. He joined the Carolina Panthers midway through last season and recently signed a three-year deal with the team worth $22 million. "If anything
column26: it proves my point from last year
column27: Reid said of his new contract. I didn't sign until the (fourth) week and did for almost the league minimum. And this year I signed a more substantial contract. And nothing has changed. I'm still the same player." Contributing: A.J. Perez Contact Tom Schad at tschad@usatoday.com or on Twitter @Tom_Schad. A link has been posted to your Facebook feed.

column2: Facts and Trends Shaping Your World About Follow  Social & Demographic Trends January 30
column3: 2019 By Anthony Cilluffo and Richard Fry The 2020 U.S. presidential election is rapidly coming into view – and so is the electorate that will determine its outcome. While demographic changes unfold slowly
column4: it’s already clear that the 2020 electorate will be unique in several ways. Nonwhites will account for a third of eligible voters – their largest share ever – driven by long-term increases among certain groups
column5: especially Hispanics. At the same time
column6: one-in-ten eligible voters will be members of Generation Z
column7: the Americans who will be between the ages 18 and 23 next year. That will occur as Millennials and all other older generations account for a smaller share of eligible voters than they did in 2016.  Pew Research Center defines the electorate as all citizens ages 18 and older living in the United States. We don’t account for those who have lost their voting rights
column8: such as people convicted of felonies living in certain states
column9: or those who can vote from outside the U.S.
column10: such as citizens living abroad and members of the armed forces stationed in other countries.  What might these demographic shifts mean politically? In 2016
column11: nonwhite voters were more likely to back Democrat Hillary Clinton
column12: while white voters were more likely to back Republican Donald Trump. Younger generations
column13: meanwhile
column14: differ notably from older generations in their views on key social and political issues. It remains unclear how these patterns might factor into the 2020 election and
column15: as always
column16: a great deal will depend on who turns out to vote. We project that the 2020 election will mark the first time that Hispanics will be the largest racial or ethnic minority group in the electorate
column17: accounting for just over 13% of eligible voters – slightly more than blacks. This change reflects the gradual but continuous growth in the Hispanic share of eligible voters
column18: up from 9% in the 2008 presidential election and 7% in the 2000 election. The black eligible voter population has grown about as fast as the electorate overall
column19: meaning their share has held constant at about 12% since 2000. In raw numbers
column20: a projected 32 million Hispanics will be eligible to vote in 2020
column21: compared with 30 million blacks. The population of Asians eligible to vote will reach an estimated 11 million in 2020
column22: which is more than double the 5 million who were eligible to vote in 2000
column23: accounting for 5% of next year’s electorate. Taken together
column24: this strong growth among minority populations means that a third of eligible voters will be nonwhite in 2020
column25: up from about a quarter in 2000. This increase is at least partially linked to immigration and naturalization patterns: One-in-ten eligible voters in the 2020 election will have been born outside the U.S.
column26: the highest share since at least 1970. Voter turnout will play an important role in determining the relative electoral influence of different racial and ethnic groups. For example
column27: while Hispanics will outnumber blacks among eligible voters next year
column28: they may not actually cast more ballots than blacks due to different turnout patterns. In recent presidential elections
column29: blacks were substantially more likely than Hispanics to vote. Indeed
column30: the number of Hispanic eligible voters who didn’t vote has exceeded the number of those who did vote in every presidential election since 1996.  Still
column31: the changing racial and ethnic composition of the electorate likely has political implications in part because nonwhites have long been significantly more likely than whites to back Democratic candidates. For instance
column32: in the 2016 election
column33: white voters favored Donald Trump by a 15 percentage point margin
column34: while large majorities of blacks and Hispanics voted for Hillary Clinton. Another important long-term trend is the overall aging of the electorate. In 2020
column35: nearly a quarter of the electorate (23%) will be ages 65 and older
column36: the highest such share since at least 1970. This reflects not only the maturation of the large Baby Boom generation but also increased life expectancy among older Americans. Baby Boomers and older generations
column37: who will be ages 56 and older next year
column38: are expected to account for fewer than four-in-ten eligible voters in 2020. This is a significant change from 2000
column39: when nearly seven-in-ten eligible voters (68%) were Boomers
column40: Silents or members of the Greatest Generation (collectively
column41: those ages 36 and older at the time). Even as recently as 2012
column42: when the youngest Boomer was 48 years old
column43: Boomer and older generations were about half of the electorate (49%). The next presidential election will also mark the first time that Millennials (who will be ages 24 to 39 in 2020) will account for a slightly smaller share of the electorate than they represented in the last presidential election. The raw number of Millennials eligible to vote is increasing due to foreign-born Millennials naturalizing to become citizens. But the Millennial share of the electorate has peaked as they are not growing as fast as the electorate overall. Meanwhile
column44: the leading edge of Generation Z (people ages 18 to 23 in 2020) is projected to comprise one-in-ten eligible voters
column45: up from just 4% in 2016
column46: when the vast majority were too young to cast ballots. These post-Millennials are on track to be more racially and ethnically diverse than their predecessors: In 2020
column47: Gen Z eligible voters are expected to be 55% white and 45% nonwhite
column48: including 21% Hispanic
column49: 14% black
column50: and 4% Asian or Pacific Islander. By comparison
column51: the Boomer and older electorate is projected to be about three-quarters white (74%).  Differences in turnout rates again matter when talking about generations and should be kept in mind as election season gets underway. Since older adults are more likely to turn out to vote
column52: it’s possible that older generations will form a larger share of actual voters in 2020 than their share in the electorate. That’s what happened in 2016: Even though Boomers and older generations accounted for 43% of eligible voters
column53: they cast 49% of the ballots. View full details on our data and methodology.  1615 L St. NW

Please read the rules before joining the discussion. America’s Founders were not big on executive power. Even after a war with Britain
column5: the Constitution’s authors saw no reason for a strong presidency. Many of the powers they assigned to presidents
column6: including staffing their own administrations
column7: were contingent on congressional approval. The authority of presidents to act unilaterally included vetoing legislation
column8: granting pardons and not much else. But over the years
column9: congresses and courts concluded that a more powerful and flexible president was needed. They indulged presidents’ sweeping claims of authority. They also enacted laws that allowed presidents to act without congressional approval and in ways not outlined in the Constitution. Notable among these is the 1976 National Emergencies Act
column10: a law that codifies presidents’ power to declare an emergency. This act
column11: as well as narrower provisions in other laws
column12: presumes that presidents would exercise these powers with great restraint and only in real emergencies
column13: not to make good on campaign promises or mollify activists within their party. The White House on Jan. 13
column15: during the government shutdown. (Photo11: Brendan Smialowski/AFP/Getty Images) REP. HICE: President was forced into declaring a national emergency Clearly that is not the case with the White House announcement Thursday that President Donald Trump would sign a bipartisan spending compromise to prevent another government shutdown but would also move more money into his border wall project (the one Mexico was supposed to pay for) by declaring a national emergency. The most obvious consequence of this destructive executive overreach is the precedent it would set for future Democratic presidents. It’s not hard to imagine them declaring emergencies to address gun violence
column16: immigration
column17: climate change
column18: medical costs and other causes of interest to the left — and Republicans howling about an imperial presidency. Assuming that Congress is unable or unwilling to overrule Trump’s emergency declaration
column19: it will almost certainly be challenged in court. That would mean a ruling on whether the situation at the border really is a national emergency. In all likelihood
column20: the answer would be no. Illegal immigration and the influx of Central American asylum seekers are significant ongoing problems
column21: not national crises like Pearl Harbor and the 9/11 attacks. The legal challenge would also invite the courts to consider the broader question of whether Congress even has the right to cede its constitutionally derived powers
column22: including the power of the purse
column23: to the president. Trump is acting unilaterally because Congress wouldn’t give him more than $1.4 billion for border barriers. All of this should prompt Republicans to ask: Is the extra wall money worth trampling on the Constitution
column24: stretching the definition of emergency
column25: setting a bad precedent and diverting money from other worthy projects? The clear answer is no. USA TODAY's editorial opinions are decided by its Editorial Board

column1: ---split---3.0---split---http://www.rollcall.com/news/republicans-have-concerns-about-trumps-executive-action-too---split---Sen. Lamar Alexander
column2: R-Tenn.
column3: said in a statement Friday that the president's national emergency declaration defies the Founders. (Photo By Bill Clark/CQ Roll Call) Some in the president’s party are wringing their hands about how the emergency declaration for a border wall might set a reckless precedent. While Congressional Republicans have raised concerns
column4: most held off on denouncing the president’s radical maneuver to circumvent Article I of the Constitution and devote federal funds to a border wall without their approval. They wonder how a future Democratic president could circumvent Congress on liberal spending priorities like the Green New Deal — the sprawling plan supported by Democratic progressives to address climate change by restructuring the economy and phasing out fossil fuels. Among the most stinging criticisms came from Sen. Lamar Alexander
column5: chairman of the Senate Appropriations subcommittee that oversees the budget for the Army Corps of Engineers. The Tennessee Republican said Trump's national emergency declaration is
column6: "is inconsistent with the U.S. Constitution" and the congressional power of the purse. In a statement
column7: Alexander also called the declaration both "unnecessary" and "unwise." “It is unwise because if this president can declare a national emergency to build a wall
column8: the next president can declare a national emergency to tear it down; or declare a climate change emergency to close coal plants and build wind turbines; or a health care emergency and force into Medicare the 180 million Americans with health insurance on the job
column9: Alexander said. “It is inconsistent with the U.S. Constitution because, after the American Revolution against a king, our founders chose not to create a chief executive with the power to tax the people and spend their money any way he chooses, said Alexander
column10: the Energy-Water chairman. "The Constitution gives that authority exclusively to a Congress elected by the people.” Rep. Cathy McMorris Rodgers
column11: R-Wash.
column12: former Republican conference chair
column13: said the declaration could subvert the balance of powers between branches of government. She said she worries it could open the door to passing a Green New Deal by fiat. “If elected president
column14: how would Elizabeth Warren or Bernie Sanders use this precedent for a national disaster declaration to force the Green New Deal on the American people?” McMorris Rodgers said in a statement. Sen. Marco Rubio
column15: R-Fla.
column16: echoed that concern. “Today’s national emergency is border security. But a future president may use this exact same tactic to impose the Green New Deal
column17: ” Rubio said in a statement. Rubio did not say whether he supported or opposed an emergency declaration
column18: but instead said he would “wait to see what statutory or constitutional power the President relies on to justify such a declaration.” Sen. Chuck Grassley
column19: R-Iowa
column20: also held off on staking a position on the national emergency declaration
column21: but underscored his support for the president’s wall push. “The Constitution grants Congress the authority to appropriate federal dollars
column22: so I’m sure such action will be litigated in the courts
column23: ” Grassley said in a statement. “What’s clear
column24: however
column25: is that the president takes the situation at our border seriously and that Democrats do not.” White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders announced in a Thursday statement that the president will sign a budget deal to avert a government shutdown. In the same statement
column26: she announced the president would “take other executive action — including a national emergency.” According to White House aides
column27: a national emergency declaration would grant Trump broad authority to redirect money appropriated to the Pentagon and U.S. Treasury in order to construct a border wall. Sen. Susan Collins
column28: R-Maine
column29: said she was concerned about how an emergency declaration would weaken the power of Congress to appropriate federal funds. It “strikes me as undermining the appropriations process
column30: the will of Congress and of being of dubious constitutionality
column31: ” Collins said in an interview with USA Today. Here are some of the other Republicans who have raised concerns about an emergency declaration for a border wall: Rep. Chris Stewart Rep. Chris Stewart
column32: R-Utah
column33: said a Democratic president could deem climate change or gun violence a national emergency in order to outmaneuver Congress on appropriating tax dollars. “Whether the president has the authority or not
column34: it sets a dangerous precedent and places America on a path that we will regret
column35: ” he said. “It deeply worries me that a future Democratic president may consider gun violence or climate change a ‘national emergency’ and what actions they may then take.” Sen. Mitt Romney Sen. Mitt Romney
column36: R-Utah
column37: supported the budget deal but said an emergency declaration is not the “right approach.” I'll reserve judgment on any potential executive action by the President until I'm able to fully evaluate it
column38: but as I’ve said
column39: I don't believe declaring a national emergency is the right approach. I'd also expect the President to stay within statutory and constitutional limits.  Sen. Rand Paul Sen. Rand Paul
column40: R-Ky.
column41: supports a border wall
column42: but the libertarian senator said he opposes the emergency declaration
column43: which he described as “extraconstitutional.” “I
column44: too
column45: want stronger border security
column46: including a wall in some areas. But how we do things matters. Over 1
column47: 000 pages dropped in the middle of the night and extraconstitutional executive actions are wrong
column48: no matter which party does them
column49: ” Paul said. Rep. Will Hurd The Texas congressman and only Republican to represent a district along the southern border
column50: said in an appearance on The View that about “1
column51: 000 landowners are going to be impacted. And guess what? They're going to sue.” Rep. Will Hurd on how landowners in his district along the border will react to the wall: "They're going to sue because in the great state of Texas
column52: we care about a little thing called 'private property rights.'" https://t.co/f8u2wc159S pic.twitter.com/5811OdClp4  Rep. Mike Turner “I supported this funding deal as a step towards securing our border
column53: which we absolutely must do. However
column54: I believe it is a dangerous precedent for the President to be forced to declare a national emergency because Congress refuses to provide necessary funding to protect our country
column55: the Ohio Republican said in a statement. As I have voiced to this Administration repeatedly
column56: I strongly believe securing our border should not be done at the expense of previously funded military construction projects.” Sen. Mike Lee The Utah Republican
column57: who supports an originalist view of the U.S. Constitution
column58: issued a gentle criticism of the president's Article I workaround on Twitter Friday afternoon. "My initial assessment is that what Pres. Trump announced is legal. Whether or not it should be legal is a different matter
column59: Lee said. Congress has been ceding far too much power to the exec. branch for decades. We should use this moment as an opportunity to start taking that power back." column1: ---split---3.0---split---http://www.rollcall.com/news/opinion/they-think-northam-should-get-another-chance-its-complicated---split---Virginia Governor Ralph Northam has been doing a lot of learning this month — about blackface
column2: apologies and redemption. African-Americans who believe he should stay in his post are used to making political compromises to survive
column3: Curtis writes. (Alex Edelman/Getty Images) OPINION — The lessons of this February’s Black History Month commemorations have already veered far beyond the usual ones that begin and end by quoting a snippet of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.’s “I Have a Dream” speech — the part about judging folks not by the color of their skin but by the content of their character. A new curriculum is being written in real time
column4: affecting real-life politicians and their constituents. And Virginia is hardly the only state not ready for the big exam. Of course
column5: the politician in question
column6: Gov. Ralph Northam
column7: has been learning as he goes — about blackface
column8: about apologies and about redemption. It is no surprise that those most qualified to teach forgiveness have been the African-American citizens of his state. They have had lots of practice since the first enslaved people were brought to Virginia 400 years ago. A Washington Post poll shows that most believe he should stay in his post and do the job he was elected to do. Part of that may be “better the devil you know.” But it is also clear in several stories published about his own history that the motivation of those who think Northam has made the right decision in choosing not to exit quietly is more complicated than that. Friends of every race who have known Northam since he grew up on Virginia’s Eastern shore paint the picture of a man who was a good
column9: fair and friendly classmate in a high school that changed from white to majority black after desegregation was finally implemented years and lawsuits after 1954’s Brown v. Board of Education. That decision led to massive official resistance to integration. Virginia closed its public schools rather than comply
column10: leaving white students to enter segregated academies and black student to fend for themselves. Also watch: Trump calls on Rep. Ilhan Omar to resign The personal and public kindnesses of Northam through high school and then college at Virginia Military Institute stood out for many who spoke with reporters. They are saddened by the caricature that has spawned outrage and Saturday Night Live skits. Reverend King also once said
column11: “It is appalling that the most segregated hour of Christian America is 11 o’clock on Sunday morning.” Though that still holds true in many communities
column12: Northam and his wife attend a church congregation with mostly black worshippers
column13: led by a black pastor. That’s not saying the embattled governor deserves a medal for acting like a human being. It is understandable that some of those voters who supported him feel betrayed. When Northam said he did not become aware until a few years ago of the pain of blackface — and when Attorney General Mark Herring confessed to his own moment imitating rap artists all too authentically — it was difficult to believe that they reached adulthood that clueless. But then it wasn’t. Teachers
column14: schools and parents are still letting children of all races down when they skip over inconvenient history
column15: when textbooks call enslaved people “workers
column16: ” “immigrants” and “indentured servants
column17: ” as Northam himself did on CBS and was quickly corrected by Gayle King. The morning anchor
column18: who is African-American
column19: would not have ascended to her prestigious job with so many blank spaces where knowledge should be. But it is still possible for white Americans to become a governor or attorney general or a CEO and have no idea about African-Americans
column20: Hispanic Americans
column21: Asian-Americans and Native Americans
column22: their histories
column23: contributions and struggles
column24: and the advantage that gave white citizens. It helps explain the inequities in wealth
column25: housing
column26: education and job opportunities whose effects persist long after slavery and Jim Crow. There is a reason some die-hard Cleveland Indians fans cling to the grinning Chief Wahoo and Covington Catholic school boys and their teachers thought war whoops and tomahawk chops were harmless fun. Which brings me
column27: and all of us
column28: to the president of the United States and Republican politicians in Virginia and beyond
column29: who are enjoying the spectacle — popcorn in hand — of Democrats imploding in a state that had been trending blue. While Northam
column30: however clumsily
column31: is calling for learning and healing
column32: the GOP looks eager to shut it and the governor down. It’s not that they are champions of liberty
column33: justice and equal opportunity for all. In fact
column34: when Donald Trump
column35: looking to take advantage
column36: took to Twitter to sow racial division by exploiting the scandals — and to compare the Democratic Party’s treatment of Northam
column37: Herring and Lt. Gov. Justin Fairfax
column38: who has denied sexual assault charges by two women — Twitter roared back
column39: reminding the president of his own road to the White House
column40: paved with birtherism and racist insults. There is plenty of evidence
column41: from housing discrimination lawsuits that padded the Trump fortune
column42: to administration policy that separated parents from children and then lost track of them
column43: to a recent possible reference to the Trail of Tears to score points on an opponent (and the current president’s worship of that policy’s father
column44: President Andrew Jackson
column45: for whom the removal of Native Americans from their land was a priority). Republicans may pull Iowa Rep. Steve King from committees as payment for his vocal support of white nationalist ideals
column46: but the congressman remains in his U.S. House seat. The African-Americans who want to give Northam another chance are used to the compromise needed to survive. In this case
column47: a governor who champions voting rights and Medicaid expansion looks pretty good compared with a GOP moving in the other direction. And most Virginians of any race realize that Republicans
column48: like Virginia Senate Majority Leader Tommy Norment
column49: managing editor of a 1968 VMI yearbook sprinkled with blackface photos and racist slurs
column50: have less than pristine racial pasts. Every February
column51: someone asks why we need a Black History Month. And every February
column52: and the rest of the year
column53: comes the proof of the price each American pays for playing politics instead of putting aside the inconvenient conversations that may cause pain
column54: but ultimately will keep the country from making the same costly mistakes over and over again. Mary C. Curtis has worked at The New York Times
column55: The Baltimore Sun
column56: The Charlotte Observer and as national correspondent for Politics Daily. Follow her on Twitter @mcurtisnc3. Get breaking news alerts and more from Roll Call on your iPhone or your Android. Follow us on Twitter and sign up for the free politics newsletter Hanging red lanterns welcome visitors to the University of Maryland’s Confucius Institute
column2: the oldest of about 100 Chinese language and cultural centers that have popped up over the last 15 years on American campuses
column3: subsidized by millions of dollars from China’s central government. Read more For decades
column4: China had no closer American friend than Dianne Feinstein. An attempt by Treasury Secretary Steven T. Mnuchin to calm plunging financial markets backfired Monday
column5: further rattling investors with new fears about whether major U.S. banks have enough cash on top of worries about interest rates
column6: political instability in Washington and a slowing global economy. He’s a failed U.S. Senate candidate with an undistinguished congressional record who
column7: for the moment
column8: is a blazing-hot 2020 presidential prospect — despite the fact that he may not run and faces long odds if he does. Months after President Trump took office
column9: Russia’s disinformation teams trained their sites on a new target: special counsel Robert S. Mueller III. Having worked to help get Trump into the White House
column10: they now worked to neutralize the biggest threat to his staying there. The Russian operatives unloaded on Mueller through fake accounts on Facebook
column11: Twitter and beyond
column12: falsely claiming that the former FBI director was corrupt and that the allegations of Russian interference in the 2016 election were crackpot conspiracies. One post on Instagram — which emerged as an especially potent weapon in the Russian social media arsenal — claimed that Mueller had worked in the past with “radical Islamic groups.” Such tactics exemplified how Russian teams ranged nimbly across social media platforms in a shrewd online influence operation aimed squarely at American voters. The effort started earlier than commonly understood and lasted longer while relying on the strengths of different sites to manipulate distinct slices of the electorate
column13: according to a pair of comprehensive new reports prepared for the Senate Intelligence Committee and released Monday. Copyright © 2019

column1: ---split---3.0---split---https://www.wired.com/story/italy-five-star-movement-techno-utopians/---split---On the night of Italy’s 2013 parliamentary elections
column2: Paola Nugnes decided to stay late at her office and catch up on work. She skipped the rolling election coverage on TV. And by the time she finally left her architecture studio to go out
column3: it was well past dark. When she arrived at Mumble Rumble
column4: a nightclub in western Naples
column5: at around 9 pm
column6: Nugnes still hadn’t checked the news. The club was hosting a party for activists in a political movement Nugnes had been part of for the past six years. And as she walked in
column7: the crowd erupted. Nugnes asked if her friend Roberto Fico
column8: the most famous local figure in the group
column9: had won his race for a seat in Parliament. But before anyone could answer
column10: a pack of journalists pounced
column11: thrusting microphones in her face: “How do you feel about being elected?” Nugnes stared at them
column12: dumbfounded. That’s how she found out she was now a senator. Along with hundreds of other political rookies
column13: Nugnes had run for office under the banner of something called Five Star
column14: an online phenomenon whose explosive
column15: organic rise was shocking even to those it had just swept into power. Just a few years before
column16: in the mid-2000s
column17: the movement had been little more than the fan base of a blog fronted by a foulmouthed comedian
column18: Beppe Grillo; from there it became an earnest protest movement organized around Meetup.com groups called Friends of Grillo; then it had unified under the name Five Star in 2009. The movement tapped deeply into one of the most powerful forces in Italian politics: disgust with Italian politics. Rather than offer an ideology or platform
column19: Five Star offered a wholesale rebuke of the country’s entrenched
column20: highly paid
column21: careerist political class—left
column22: right
column23: and center. And it married that disdain to a grand techno-utopian project: Through an online voting and debate portal
column24: Five Star was building a direct democracy on the internet. The long-term goal was to replace Parliament altogether—to automate it out of existence. But in the meantime
column25: Five Star had also decided to displace the establishment seat by seat. How Trump Could Wind up Making Globalism Great Again The Political Education of Silicon Valley Why Tech Worker Dissent Is Going Viral The 2013 election was Five Star’s first foray into national politics. While a handful of its candidates were expected to win their races
column26: Nugnes highly doubted she would be one of them; she barely gave it a thought
column27: in fact. So Nugnes had worked through the evening
column28: while the rest of the country reeled from the news that Five Star was now Italy’s second-biggest party
column29: having swept 25 percent of the vote
column30: upending the political establishment in a single stroke. Amid the whirl of embraces and congratulations at the election night party
column31: Nugnes struggled to think through the ramifications. “We were all very excited—and frightened
column32: ” she says. She would have to quit her architecture studio. “It was very traumatic
column33: ” she says. A couple hours’ drive up the coast
column34: near Rome
column35: Elena Fattori
column36: a molecular biologist who was also active in Five Star
column37: faced a similar bout of disbelief that night. “I had taken it all very lightly
column38: ” she says of her run for the senate—so much so that she volunteered to help supervise the vote count that day. As she watched the running tally
column39: Fattori could see firsthand that Five Star was far exceeding expectations and
column40: eventually
column41: that she herself had been elected. “It was a shock
column42: ” Fattori tells me. “I took a couple of days to accept it.” All told
column43: some 160 Five Star candidates with virtually no experience in politics became members of Parliament that day. This put the movement in an awkward position. Governments in Italy are normally formed via alliances between two or more parties that can command a majority of seats in Parliament; Five Star had won so many seats that it had the option of going straight into a governing coalition with the first-placed bloc
column44: led by the center-left Democratic Party. But that was out of the question: One of Five Star’s founding principles was “no alliances.” And besides
column45: the movement saw the Democratic Party as central to the corrupt establishment it had sworn to fight. So Five Star went into opposition. While Five Star sees itself as neither right- nor left-wing
column46: much of the party’s base is left-leaning. Many of its voters and activists
column47: including Fattori and Nugnes
column48: were drawn to the movement after becoming disenchanted with the Democrats and other parties on the left. Nugnes
column49: a woman with Marxist sympathies
column50: had grown alienated from Italy’s communist parties
column51: which she viewed as ailing
column52: top-down institutions. “I felt like an orphan
column53: ” she recalls. Five Star
column54: by contrast
column55: was a “cultural revolution
column56: ” a horizontal movement that put governing directly in the hands of anyone who cared to log on. To the extent that Five Star did have a political platform
column57: it vaguely resembled that of a Green Party. The movement’s name ostensibly refers to its first five policy priorities: sustainable transportation
column58: sustainable development
column59: public water
column60: universal internet access
column61: and environmentalism. Nugnes was particularly attracted to the movement’s more recent flagship policy
column62: a universal basic income that proposed a monthly stipend of 780 euros (a bit less than $900) for Italy’s poorest citizens. In short: While the movement had always included people across the political spectrum
column63: it was easily taken for a progressive popular front. Members of Five Star reeled at where their movement had ended up: tied to a party led by a man many of them regarded as a fascist. But if Nugnes and Fattori were shocked to become elected members of government
column64: the next few years would be even more vertiginous. As the movement’s fledgling nonpoliticians found their feet in Parliament
column65: they realized that dealing with other parties was unavoidable. At times
column66: in opposing the Democratic Party–led government
column67: Five Star found itself siding with another faction defined by antiestablishment roots—a right-wing populist party called Lega
column68: or the League. Lega’s nativist leader
column70: had long campaigned on an “Italians first” platform. He has said that his country needs a “mass cleansing” of illegal immigrants
column73: piazza by piazza.” When Italy’s 2018 national elections came around
column74: Five Star—whose emphasis on popular sovereignty had
column76: come to sound sympatico with anti-EU
column77: anti-immigrant sentiment—won so many seats that it became the largest party in Italy. This time
column78: the movement didn’t shy from stepping up to run the country. And it chose to do so in partnership with Salvini’s Lega. Last September
column80: former chief strategist to Donald Trump and would-be pied piper to Europe’s ethno-nationalists
column81: visited Rome to celebrate the alliance. Of all the countries he had visited in his recent travels
column82: he singled out Italy as “the center of the political universe.” The new government there was a Bannonite dream come true: a left-right
column83: antiestablishment coalition. “A populist party with nationalist tendencies like the Five Stars
column84: and a nationalist party with populist tendencies like the League
column85: ” he enthused to Politico’s European edition. “It’s imperative that this works
column86: because this shows a model for industrial democracies from the US to Asia.” While Bannon gushed
column87: members of Five Star like Nugnes and Fattori reeled at where their movement had ended up: tied to a party led by a man many of them regarded as a fascist. They were also beginning to realize that Five Star’s evolution had never been as organic as it seemed. At every step along the way—from the creation of Grillo’s blog and the organization of the movement’s first mass protests to the construction of its direct-democracy platform
column88: all the way to its recent turn toward nativist politics—Five Star’s course had been meticulously directed by a camera-shy cyber-utopian named Gianroberto Casaleggio
column90: who died of brain cancer in 2016
column93: a familiar type. In the 1990s and early 2000s
column94: he and a slew of other Internet Age prophets—many of them writing in this magazine—foretold a digital revolution that would flatten the priesthoods of politics
column97: and replace them with decentralized webs of direct participation. But Casaleggio
column99: actually went on to mount a revolutionary force that took over a country. Not only that
column100: he directed this supposedly leaderless movement while drawing barely any attention to himself. So here’s the mystery at the heart of Five Star: Who the hell was Gianroberto Casaleggio—and how did he do it? Gianroberto Casaleggio: Cofounder and intellectual father of the movement. Beppe Grillo: The movement’s cofounder and front man. Luigi Di Maio: A Casaleggio protégé
column101: elected the leader of Five Star in 2017. Alessandro Di Battista: Another Casaleggio protégé and one of the movement’s most visible members. Roberto Fico: Unofficial leader of Five Star’s left wing. Paola Nugnes: Left-wing Five Star senator who has been critical of the movement’s rightward turn. The small city of Ivrea sits cradled in the foothills of the Italian Alps
column102: 30 miles south of the Swiss border. An 18th-century bridge over the Dora Baltea river leads to a quaint historic downtown of cobbled streets and pastel-colored buildings. But in the 1970s
column103: Ivrea was Italy’s answer to Silicon Valley. It was the hometown of Olivetti
column104: an icon of postwar European design
column106: and manufacturing. The company’s most famous devices—its portable typewriters—were the Apple products of their day
column107: technological fetish objects that were coveted around the world. In the early days of the computer industry
column108: Olivetti was one of the few European contenders for market dominance; in 1965
column109: it released the world’s first device marketed commercially as a “desktop computer.” The young Gianroberto Casaleggio was one of Olivetti’s software designers. A local with a long mane of frizzy hair
column110: he had studied physics in college before dropping out and turning to computers. He ended up in a small office on a quiet lane developing Olivetti’s operating systems. Enrica Zublena
column111: an engineer who worked next to Casaleggio for many years
column112: remembers their early days at the company as an exciting time. “We thought we could become a reference point for the evolution of basic IT around the world
column113: ” Zublena says. Olivetti was a heady place to work in other ways as well
column114: especially for anyone prone to utopian thinking. Adriano Olivetti
column115: the late owner and general manager of the firm
column116: had run his company as a kind of philosopher-CEO. He built futuristic factories and living complexes for his workers in Ivrea and advocated a “third way” between right and left sociopolitical thinking; he started his own political movement—a fusion of liberalism
column118: and local self-determinism—which took him all the way to Parliament. He also wrote books expounding on his views. In one
column120: he argued that technology should be used to hand the mechanics of politics back to citizens. Casaleggio shared Olivetti’s interest in the transformative potential of computing. “We saw the birth of the client-server model in IT
column121: ” Zublena says—the emergence of systems that distribute tasks among many computers in a network
column122: allowing distant nodes to cooperate. “It brought a level of decisionmaking freedom to the periphery.” It seemed inevitable to Casaleggio that such architectures would change everything in society. By the 1990s
column123: Casaleggio was running his own company
column124: and it was his turn to play philosopher-CEO. The firm
column126: quickly became one of the leading internet consulting outfits in Italy
column127: doing a brisk business helping older firms to find “web-based solutions” and otherwise navigate the bewildering world of bits
column129: and online marketing. “It was the time of the first call centers
column132: who followed her colleague to Webegg. But Casaleggio was impatient to explore the grander implications of the internet. In a monthly column for a magazine called Web Marketing Tools
column133: he inveighed against the drabness of most thinking about the web. “The net has been reduced to an instrument of financial speculation and marketing
column135: but its true significance was as a force for “radical social and revolutionary change.” Perhaps most of all
column136: Casaleggio was interested in how the internet would transform organizations from the inside. Accordingly
column137: he turned Webegg into a laboratory for sometimes bizarre social experimentation. Throughout his career
column138: Casaleggio liked to give extraordinary responsibilities to his youngest
column140: and most impressionable recruits. One such hire at Webegg was a Bolognese engineer named Carlo Baffè. When he arrived fresh out of school in 1997
column141: Baffè was promptly handed the reins to one of the company’s biggest projects. “Don’t worry
column142: ” Casaleggio reassured him. “Napoleon invaded Italy when he was 26.” About a year later
column143: Baffè got another call. “I have this new special project in mind
column144: ” Casaleggio told him. “Would you like to join?” Baffè accepted eagerly. He went to the company’s Milan headquarters and
column145: in a meeting room near Casaleggio’s office
column146: sat at a circular table with the CEO and four other young
column148: all from different parts of the firm. Casaleggio explained that the aim of this new project was to experiment with communication dynamics on the company’s intranet. Casaleggio would select topics from the firm’s internal forum and assign members of the group specific roles to play in each discussion. Say he wanted a forum debate to reach conclusion X: One member of the restricted group would suggest X
column149: a second would argue for contradictory conclusion Y
column150: and over time a third would post a variation on X—and so on
column151: subtly driving the rest of the unwitting employees toward the preordained conclusion. Baffè and the other experimenters worked a few hours a week on the project and met with Casaleggio once a month to evaluate progress. The original stated aim of the project was to observe how internal electronic communications worked
column152: and then to sell the findings as a consulting service. But the experiment also had more far-reaching implications
column153: Baffè realized. Casaleggio was interested in learning how consensus—on
column155: whether people should be happy to work long hours—could be manufactured in a way that looked organic. Twenty years before trolls working for Russia’s Internet Research Agency would use similar techniques to steer debate on Facebook and other online forums
column156: Casaleggio seemed to be using his own company as a laboratory to figure out how online discourse could be guided from above. “I’d just started working and was excited to be part of a project like that
column157: ” Baffè says. It wasn’t until years later
column159: that he “realized it was the beginning of a long-term experiment.” The intranet study group was only one such special project. Baffè was also invited to join another select group of about 20 employees who were given advanced communications training
column160: grounded in something called neuro-linguistic programming. A new-age therapeutic phenomenon
column161: NLP purportedly offers a means to influence people by surreptitiously tapping into the unconscious patterns that guide their behavior. Practitioners are taught that people can be “reprogrammed” —to shed a phobia
column163: or desire a product—with relative ease. “It taught us how to classify people
column164: ” Baffè says: By identifying which kinds of metaphors a client favored
column165: employees at Webegg could aim to “mirror” that client
column166: making them more susceptible to the company’s message. The sessions also focused on the teachings of an American hypnotherapist named Milton H. Erickson
column167: who likewise made extraordinary claims about the suggestibility of the unconscious mind. By subtly confusing and unsettling his patients
column168: Erickson claimed that he could induce them into trance states that made them more pliable. (NLP is popular among sales gurus and with the modern pickup artist community
column169: but psychologists tend to regard it as a pseudoscience.) The monthly sessions were led by two psychologists
column171: and they were a bit like “group therapy
column172: ” Baffè says. Employees were encouraged to air their feelings. At first
column173: Baffè was thrilled to take part. But gradually his enthusiasm waned as he began to wonder who
column175: was being influenced. The psychologists were seemingly omnipresent in the Webegg offices
column176: where they appeared to be keeping tabs on staff for Casaleggio. “I’m sure he controlled every single detail of their activity
column177: ” Baffè says. (WIRED spoke to one of the psychologists
column178: who confirmed that she had worked with Webegg and called Casaleggio a “true visionary” but declined to be interviewed.) In practice
column181: and psychological interventions often seemed to be a means of bypassing directors and team leaders—the firm’s middlemen—to exert maximal influence over his staff. “The channel is direct between the boss and every employee
column183: the young engineer started to see Casaleggio as an “evil scientist.” This impression was reinforced by his boss’s increasingly eccentric behavior. During the Y2K panic
column184: Casaleggio printed out a “decalogue”—a set of 10 commandments—telling employees what to do if civilization collapsed. He wrote a magazine column praising Genghis Khan’s (apocryphal) practice of murdering his generals at random as an effective means of keeping subordinates and intermediaries on their toes. Khan
column186: “became the greatest conqueror in history with the application of techniques and principles that are necessary today to compete on the web.” “The interactive leader will then be the new politician
column188: “someone who continually transforms the wishes of public opinion into reality.” But even as he praised Khan’s absolute rule
column189: Casaleggio also extolled the absolute power that masses of people would have over their leaders in the internet era. In a 2001 book entitled The Web Is Dead
column191: Casaleggio described how technology would force governments to become completely transparent and accountable to the will of the people. “Referenda on topics of national importance will become as routine as reading the papers or the evening news
column192: ” he wrote. “The interactive leader will then be the new politician
column193: someone who continually transforms the wishes of public opinion into reality. This new politician will not need interpretation by today’s media
column194: which will thus lose their importance.” Like any number of cyber-utopians writing in places like WIRED—several of whose writers he cited in his work—Casaleggio repeatedly predicted the imminent demise of journalism. He held that in a few years
column197: pervading people’s daily lives; it would replace the current “virtual reality” that the press had constructed for them
column198: “the Matrix that surrounds us.” To his point
column199: the media Matrix in Italy was exceptionally claustrophobic: In 2001
column200: the scandal-prone media tycoon Silvio Berlusconi had just begun his second term as prime minister; not only did he own the biggest commercial television network
column201: he also dominated the state broadcaster
column202: RAI. While Casaleggio was busy peering into the future
column203: he was neglecting more run-of-the-mill sources of revenue that Webegg needed to turn a profit. “He put all the best people on the new stuff that was very sexy for him
column204: ” Baffè says. But the company’s core business foundered. “At some point
column206: “his ego took over.” Amid mounting financial losses
column207: Casaleggio was forced out in 2003 by the company’s main shareholder
column208: Telecom Italia. Webegg closed shortly thereafter. Casaleggio had the contacts and experience to remain a player in the Italian tech industry
column209: but by then his interest in the early internet was pivoting from business to another arena: politics. Even those who knew Casaleggio well (but who perhaps didn’t read his books closely) were surprised by the sudden turn. Zublena remembers telling him
column211: you’ve never been remotely interested in politics!” In response
column212: the usually taciturn Casaleggio burst out laughing
column213: exposing the boyish gap between his front two teeth. “Come on
column215: “with all the things in the world
column216: you’re going into politics?” But Casaleggio only laughed and kept his reasons to himself. Edoardo Narduzzi
column217: who had known Casaleggio since 1998 and served as a Webegg board member
column218: thinks Casaleggio saw “an interesting space” in Italian politics
column219: ripe for testing out his ideas for a web-based
column220: bottom-up movement—“a political startup.” It all began with a simple punt. In 2004
column221: Casaleggio ran as an independent candidate in his home village
column222: near Ivrea. Out of 294 votes cast for a seat on a local council
column223: Casaleggio won just six. That didn’t mean he would give up. All he needed was a front man. As Italy’s top barnstorming comedian
column224: Beppe Grillo was accustomed to overzealous fans. But none made an impression like the visitor who came to see him one night in April 2004. After a show in the coastal city of Livorno
column225: Gianroberto Casaleggio appeared at Grillo’s dressing room door and introduced himself as a web entrepreneur. But with his shock of wild gray hair
column229: he seemed more like an “evil genius.” Grillo recounts this first meeting in a preface he wrote for Casaleggio’s next book
column230: Web Ergo Sum. “He explained webcasting to me
column241: ” Grillo recalled. He likened Casaleggio to the medieval radical Saint Francis of Assisi
column242: but “instead of talking to wolves and to the birds
column243: he spoke to the internet.” The comedian was initially wary: “Everything was clear
column245: “he was a madman.” But Casaleggio’s madness was one that envisioned a better future thanks to the web: companies made democratic
column247: and the devolution of power down to the individual. Before long
column248: Grillo fell under Casaleggio’s spell—which was remarkable

Steve Bannon—the former White House chief strategist and far-right impresario—has been trying to unify Europe’s most strident populists into a supergroup called the Movement. Some nationalists have been receptive; others see him as an unwelcome foreign influence. (Go figure.) Five Star has held off on joining. Here’s how Bannon has fared elsewhere. —Graham Hacia BELGIUM - Mischaël Modrikamen: Cofounder of the Belgian People’s Party. Helped establish the Movement. ITALY - Matteo Salvini: Interior minister and leader of the anti-immigrant party Lega. Said his party would join. UK - Jacob Rees-Mogg: Pro-Brexit conservative parliamentarian. HUNGARY - Viktor Orbán: Prime minister and leader of the nationalist Fidesz party. Praised the idea but hasn’t committed. SPAIN - Santiago Abascal: Leader of Spain’s ultraconservative VOX party. column2: Facts and Trends Shaping Your World About Follow  Social & Demographic Trends Among Republicans

column4: climate and the role of government By Kim Parker
column5: Nikki Graf and Ruth Igielnik  No longer the new kids on the block
column6: Millennials have moved firmly into their 20s and 30s
column7: and a new generation is coming into focus. Generation Z – diverse and on track to be the most well-educated generation yet – is moving toward adulthood with a liberal set of attitudes and an openness to emerging social trends. On a range of issues
column8: from Donald Trump’s presidency to the role of government to racial equality and climate change
column9: the views of Gen Z – those ages 13 to 21 in 2018 – mirror those of Millennials.1 In each of these realms
column10: the two younger generations hold views that differ significantly from those of their older counterparts. In most cases
column11: members of the Silent Generation are at the opposite end
column12: and Baby Boomers and Gen Xers fall in between.2 It’s too early to say with certainty how the views of this new generation will evolve. Most have yet to reach voting age
column13: and their outlook could be altered considerably by changing national conditions
column14: world events or technological innovations. Even so
column15: two new Pew Research Center surveys
column16: one of U.S. teens ages 13 to 17 and one of adults ages 18 and older
column17: provide some compelling clues about where they may be headed and how their views could impact the nation’s political landscape. Only about three-in-ten Gen Zers and Millennials (30% and 29%
column18: respectively) approve of the way Donald Trump is handling his job as president. This compares with 38% of Gen Xers
column19: 43% of Boomers and 54% of Silents. Similarly
column20: while majorities in Gen Z and the Millennial generation say government should do more to solve problems
column21: rather than that government is doing too many things better left to businesses and individuals
column22: Gen Xers and Boomers are more evenly divided on this issue. For their part
column23: most Silents would like to see a less activist government. When it comes to views on race
column24: the two younger generations are more likely than older generations to say that blacks are treated less fairly than whites in the United States today. And they are much more likely than their elders to approve of NFL players kneeling during the national anthem as a sign of protest. The younger generations are also more accepting of some of the ways in which American society is changing. Majorities among Gen Z and the Millennial generation say increasing racial and ethnic diversity in the U.S. is a good thing for society
column25: while older generations are less convinced of this. And they’re more likely to have a positive view of interracial and same-sex marriage than their older counterparts. As a recent Pew Research Center report highlighted
column26: Gen Z is the most racially and ethnically diverse generation we have seen
column27: but this isn’t all that’s driving the attitudes of this generation when it comes to issues surrounding race and diversity. There are significant
column28: if more modest

column90: 29% approve). Gen Zers and Millennials share similar views about racial and ethnic change in the country.
