column1: ---split---8.0---split---https://www.npr.org/2019/02/14/694977662/emergency-declaration-for-border-wall-could-tap-military-funds---split---David Welna During his State of the Union speech this month
column2: President Trump reiterated his call for funding of a wall to block unauthorized migration across the Southern border. Andrew Harnik/AP hide caption During his State of the Union speech this month
column3: President Trump reiterated his call for funding of a wall to block unauthorized migration across the Southern border. After weeks of brandishing the threat of invoking a national emergency
column4: President Trump is going ahead and declaring one. "President Trump will sign the government funding bill
column5: White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders said Thursday afternoon, and as he has stated before
column6: he will also take other executive action — including a national emergency — to ensure we stop the national security and humanitarian crisis at the border." Trump had earlier declared his unhappiness with the $1.375 billion that Congress is providing for a border barrier in a spending bill that keeps the government operating through the end of September. That outlay is less than a quarter of the $5.7 billion Trump had sought for a wall along the border with Mexico. By declaring a national emergency at the same time he signs the legislation keeping the government open
column7: Trump is aiming to amass additional funding for that wall from what acting White House chief of staff Mick Mulvaney has called "pots of money" in federal agencies. A possible source for fattening border wall funding would be the billions of dollars appropriated this year for military construction. A 1982 law empowers the secretary of defense to redirect military construction funds during a presidentially declared national emergency. But tapping money meant for building military housing or improving safety on bases could be problematic. "You can use military construction funding under a national emergency
column8: but it actually stipulates that that has to be for a military purpose
column9: and it would be hard to justify this
column10: I think
column11: is a military purpose
column12: says military budget expert Todd Harrison of the Center for Strategic and International Studies. So if [Trump] did that
column13: he's likely to end up with a court challenge
column14: which could forestall the whole thing for months or even years." NPR thanks our sponsors Become an NPR sponsor

column1: ---split---8.0---split---http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2019/02/14/more-people-around-the-world-see-u-s-power-and-influence-as-a-major-threat-to-their-country/---split---Numbers
column2: Facts and Trends Shaping Your World About Follow  By John Gramlich and Kat Devlin A growing share of people around the world see U.S. power and influence as a “major threat” to their country
column3: and these views are linked with attitudes toward President Donald Trump and the United States as a whole
column4: according to Pew Research Center surveys conducted in 22 nations since 2013. A median of 45% across the surveyed nations see U.S. power and influence as a major threat
column5: up from 38% in the same countries during Trump’s first year as president in 2017 and 25% in 2013
column6: during the administration of Barack Obama. The long-term increase in the share of people who see American power as a threat has occurred alongside declines in the shares of people who say they have confidence in the U.S. president to do the right thing regarding world affairs and who have a favorable view of the United States. (For more about global views toward the U.S. president and the country he leads
column7: see “Trump’s International Ratings Remain Low
column8: Especially Among Key Allies.”) Despite these changes
column9: U.S. power and influence still ranks below other perceived threats around the world. Considerably larger shares of people point to global climate change (seen as a major threat by a median of 67%)
column10: the Islamic militant group known as ISIS (cited by 62%) and cyberattacks (cited by 61%). U.S. power and influence
column11: in fact
column12: is not seen as the top threat in any of the countries surveyed.  Still
column13: in 18 of the 22 countries
column14: there were statistically significant increases in the share of people who see American power and influence as a major threat between 2013 and 2018. That includes increases of 30 percentage points in Germany
column15: 29 points in France
column16: and 26 points in Brazil and Mexico. And while these shares rose substantially in many countries after Trump’s election
column17: they increased further in several nations between Trump’s first and second year in office. In Germany and France
column18: for instance
column19: the share of people who see U.S. power and influence as a major threat went up by 14 and 13 percentage points
column20: respectively
column21: between 2017 and 2018. Other notable year-over-year increases occurred in Tunisia (11 points)
column22: Canada and Argentina (8 points each)
column23: South Africa (7 points) and Brazil and Russia (6 points each). Other nations bucked this trend
column24: however. In Spain
column25: for example
column26: the share of people who see American power as a major threat fell by 17 points between 2017 and 2018 (from 59% to 42%). Still
column27: people in Spain remain much more likely to see the U.S. as a threat today than in 2013. Overall
column28: there are 10 nations surveyed where roughly half or more now see U.S. power as a major threat
column29: with the biggest shares saying this in South Korea (67%)
column30: Japan (66%) and Mexico (64%). In South Korea
column31: equal shares point to U.S. power and influence and to North Korea’s nuclear program as a major threat to their nation (each is cited by 67% of the public). However
column32: several other perceived threats to South Koreans outrank U.S. power and influence
column33: including global climate change (named by 86% of South Koreans)
column34: China’s power and influence (cited by 82%)
column35: cyberattacks from other countries (cited by 81%) and the condition of the global economy (cited by 74%). South Koreans have long perceived American power as a major threat to their country: 66% said this in 2013 and 70% said it in 2017. In many of the surveyed countries
column36: concerns about American power and influence are connected with views of Trump: People who have little or no confidence in the U.S. president to do the right thing regarding world affairs are more likely than those who have confidence in Trump to see U.S. power and influence as a top threat to their country. This includes several longtime U.S. allies
column37: including Canada
column38: the UK and Australia. The same pattern appears when it comes to views of the U.S. in general
column39: as opposed to its president. In most surveyed nations
column40: people who have a more unfavorable view of the U.S. are also more likely to say that American power and influence is a threat to their nation. Topics: U.S. Global Image and Anti-Americanism
column41: Country Image

column1: ---split---9.0---split---https://www.huffpost.com/entry/trump-national-emergency-didnt-need_n_5c66e76ce4b05c889d1ed6bf---split---President Donald Trump on Friday admitted that he “didn’t need to” declare a national emergency for his long-promised border wall
column2: and merely wanted to “do it much faster” to please his political base. A number of legal experts — including George Conway
column3: husband of top Trump adviser Kellyanne Conway — immediately noted on Twitter that those words could easily be used against him in the likely legal battle over his questionable claim to a national emergency. This quote should be the first sentence of the first paragraph of every complaint filed this afternoon. https://t.co/ClHQhpTaEe Hours after Trump’s announcement
column4: Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington (CREW) announced a lawsuit against the Department of Justice “because the government has so far failed” to explain why the wall could be considered a national emergency. Trump openly acknowledged the possibility of lawsuits during his remarks Friday
column5: predicting that he would lose in the lower courts. It would not be the first time Trump’s words have been used against him in court. The ACLU
column6: which has frequently sued Trump and his administration
column7: announced Friday it would file a lawsuit “early next week” challenging Trump’s decision. “This is a patently illegal power grab that hurts American communities and flouts the checks and balances that are hallmarks of our democracy
column8: ” ACLU Executive Director Anthony Romero said. Omar Jadwat
column9: the director of ACLU’s Immigrant Rights Project
column10: urged the president to “keep talking” in a tweet posted during Trump’s remarks. keep talking mr president Following his announcement Friday
column11: Trump is heading to his golf club in Florida for the weekend
column12: further underscoring the dubious nature of his “national emergency.” This story has been updated to note lawsuits from CREW and the ACLU. Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? Here’s how.

column1: ---split---9.0---split---https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/15/opinion/language-euphemisms-trump.html---split---Supported by Language has been neutralized when it should state the obvious. By Timothy Egan Contributing Opinion Writer You could always slight the very rich by calling them moneybags
column2: robber barons
column3: fat cats or plutocrats. Billionaire was a neutral word
column4: grounded in math: Such a person could spend $10 million a year
column5: for 100 years
column6: before the pile was gone. Then came Howard Schultz
column7: a billionaire times two
column8: insisting that people not use the B-word in describing him. Better to refer to the 540 Americans in his sensitive class as “people of means.” For this he was roundly mocked
column9: and rightly so. The pushback to the pusher of our favorite South American drug is a fair start. But there is much more to clean up. For we live in a time when language has been weaponized for high crimes and petty cruelties
column10: while neutralized when it should state the obvious. Democracy may die in darkness
column11: as the slogan of a rival newspaper has it
column12: but it also slips away under cover of euphemism. You can date it to Republican repackaging of the estate tax as a “death tax
column13: ” or tax cuts for the rich morphing into “tax relief” for the overly burdened. And were French fries really “freedom fries” during a spasm of faux-patriotism? Maybe the food marketers started us down this road when “natural” was slapped onto any label — turpentine
column14: for example
column15: which also happens to be gluten-free. Or Big Pharma
column16: using “wellness” to describe treatment by drugs with names from a dance party: Lyrica
column17: Celebrex
column18: and then the Cialis gets passed around. All of that can be excused as framing to get an advantage. The Democrats are doing it now with the Green New Deal and Medicare for All — both of which sound pleasantly pie-in-the-sky and historically resonant until you look at the details
column19: which their sponsors didn’t bother to do. The most egregious of political language fraud
column20: as George Orwell noted in his seminal essay on the subject
column21: is used for “the defense of the indefensible.” To that end
column22: the Trump administration has been a fount of criminal circumlocution. We all know about “alternative facts” and “truth isn’t truth” and “fake news” — used by the administration to describe reality. But less attention has been paid to this government’s description of cages for young children separated from their parents. The Trump administration has invented “tender age” shelters to defend the indefensible. It sounds so caring. And Trump is downgrading “national emergency” from something that comes with a siren for a soundtrack to just another term for cheap political expediency. It used to be a big deal for a reputable news organization to flat out call the president a liar. Now
column23: liar must be the most-used descriptor linked to this president. It’s also the right word. But “liar” has lost its sting
column24: because Trump clearly doesn’t care about telling the truth. As a journalist
column25: I’d get in more trouble if I said the president is fat — my bad
column26: I mean plus-sized. The word “socialist” is back in play. This term also used to sting
column27: evoking Cold War authoritarians and empty store shelves. That was true then. What’s true now is that socialist “has lost its meaning
column28: ” especially among millennials
column29: as Peter Buttigieg
column30: the young presidential aspirant and mayor of South Bend
column31: Ind.
column32: said. If used to describe help for the elderly
column33: subsidized college or affordable health care
column34: socialist is a net plus. If it implies total government control without choice
column35: it’s a loser. We’ve only just begun the modern reframing of this power word. At the White House
column36: “executive time” is the bogus term for the majority of the president’s day spent watching Fox News hosts praise him
column37: tweeting insults or playing virtual golf in the new room-sized simulator just installed in the house where Lincoln slept. Kramer did more work in the “Seinfeld” episode where he pretended to have a job. The border “wall” is a “complexifier
column38: ” to use the odd word that multibillionaire Jeff Bezos introduced
column39: but also central to Trumpian Newspeak. The wall doesn’t exist
column40: not in the form Trump has described it — “a great
column41: great wall” made of “hardened concrete.” And yet
column42: it’ll soon be finished. How so? In a masterstroke of up-is-down
column43: Trump’s rally in El Paso this week switched the “Build the Wall” slogan of his cult to “Finish the Wall.” As my colleagues at Upshot showed
column44: Trump keeps weaseling out of his wall promise by changing the wording — a fence
column45: a barrier
column46: some German shepherds. The language is crucial here
column47: because it’s the central lie of his presidency. Like Schultz
column48: Trump wants to use his own verbal wallpaper to cover the truth. I invite you to follow me on Twitter (@nytegan). The Times is committed to publishing a diversity of letters to the editor. We’d like to hear what you think about this or any of our articles. Here are some tips. And here’s our email: letters@nytimes.com. Follow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook
column49: Twitter (@NYTopinion) and Instagram. Advertisement

column1: ---split---9.0---split---http://www.rollcall.com/news/congress/democrats-will-push-back-on-national-emergency-in-congress-and-courts-pelosi-schumer-say---split---Speaker Nancy Pelosi
column2: D-Calif.
column3: and Senate Minority Leader Charles Schumer
column4: D-N.Y.
column5: said Democrats will push back against the president's national emergency declaration in Congress
column6: the courts and the public. (Photo By Tom Williams/CQ Roll Call) Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer promise that Democrats in Congress — hopefully joined by some Republicans — will push back against President Donald Trump’s national emergency declaration in multiple arenas. “The President’s actions clearly violate the Congress’ exclusive power of the purse
column7: which our founders enshrined in the Constitution
column8: ” the duo said in a joint statement Friday. “The Congress will defend our constitutional authorities in the Congress
column9: in the courts
column10: and in the public
column11: using every remedy available.” Pelosi and Schumer did not provide specifics regarding the actions they’ll take. But there’s already talk of the House passing a resolution of disapproval
column12: rejecting the emergency declaration. Under the National Emergencies Act of 1976
column13: presidents can take extraordinary actions in times of crisis by declaring a national emergency. A joint resolution disapproving of action under the 1976 law would be considered “privileged” and can be passed with a simple majority vote in each chamber. The privileged status of such a resolution would allow Senate Democrats to force a floor vote over objections of Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell
column14: who said Thursday he supports Trump’s decision. During a Rose Garden announcement Friday
column15: Trump said he would sign a national emergency declaration stating there’s a crisis at the southern border. He plans to shift $3.5 billion from the Defense Department’s military construction fund to the border barrier project. “The President’s unlawful declaration over a crisis that does not exist does great violence to our Constitution and makes America less safe
column16: stealing from urgently needed defense funds for the security of our military and our nation
column17: ” Pelosi and Schumer said. “This is plainly a power grab by a disappointed President
column18: who has gone outside the bounds of the law to try to get what he failed to achieve in the constitutional legislative process.” The Democratic leaders’ promise that Congress will respond in the courts comes as no surprise to the administration. Trump said Friday he expects to get sued and even to get an initial “bad ruling
column19: ” but he expressed confidence the Supreme Court will uphold his declaration. Democrats are likely to coordinate legal action with states and local governments — and potentially
column20: outside interest groups —that will want to sue Trump over the declaration. “The president’s emergency declaration
column21: if unchecked
column22: would fundamentally alter the balance of powers
column23: inconsistent with our founders’ vision
column24: ” Pelosi and Schumer said. Some Republicans have said they do not support Trump using an emergency declaration to go around Congress. But it’s unclear whether they feel strongly enough to get involved in any court action
column25: or to support a resolution of disapproval. Pelosi and Schumer are hoping they will
column26: saying
column27: “We call upon our Republican colleagues to join us to defend the Constitution. Just as both parties honored our oath to protect the American people by passing the conference committee bill
column28: the Congress on a bipartisan basis must honor the Constitution by defending our system of checks and balances.” The Democratic leaders’ statement focused on Trump’s national emergency declaration. It was not immediately clear if they will also seek to challenge his authority to use other executive actions to shift additional money toward the border barrier project. The Trump administration is planning actions that would divert $2.5 billion from the Pentagon’s drug interdiction initiative and $600 million from a Treasury Department drug forfeiture program. White House officials said Friday those funds will “back-filled” in Trump’s fiscal 2020 budget request. John T. Bennett

column1: ---split---9.0---split---https://www.yahoo.com/author/matt-bai---split---Pete Buttigieg would rather talk about his record as the two-term mayor of South Bend
column2: Ind.
column3: than about his identity as the first openly gay man to seek the Democratic nomination. Our developer president could have focused his energy on building airports
column4: high-speed rail lines and high-tech schools. But he can only think of one place to sink a shovel
column5: and that’s turning out to be the sinkhole of his administration. Howard Schultz is one of very few people on the planet who had the vision to transform the way we live. He saw where the culture was headed and figured out a way to get ahead of it. No one in politics is doing that. The question facing former Ohio Gov. John Kasich
column6: if he decides to run against Trump
column7: is this: Do you try to take out the incumbent president in the primaries
column8: or do you make an independent bid instead? President Trump doesn’t think our defense of democratic values really works for America anymore
column9: and in this he has more in common with Vladimir Putin than he does with his own Cabinet or his military. In Trump’s America
column10: taking personal responsibility for anything you say or do is suddenly out of vogue
column11: no matter which side you’re on or how petty the issue. Back in 2015
column12: I sat down with President Obama
column13: during a visit to Nike’s Oregon campus
column14: to talk about the huge Asian trade pact he was trying to sell. It was what Obama said that day about Elizabeth Warren
column15: who had become a vocal critic of the trade deal
column16: that landed like a grenade. What crude and awful The contrast to focus on in 2020 isn’t just right versus left. It’s short term versus long term. It’s quarterly returns versus a half century of peril. When Trump flouts the conventions of the office
column17: he’s winning with his core voters. It doesn’t matter what he’s saying — what matters is that he’s making the rest of us howl in indignation. It was hard to watch George H.W. Bush’s funeral proceedings this week and not wonder how Donald Trump’s last farewell will someday compare. A few of the Democratic Party’s young stars in the House took on Nancy Pelosi this week and proved mainly that none of them have anything like the political acumen to replace her. In a movie where virtually all the characters live in a gray zone of morality
column18: should the journalists be exempt? Do we have to choose between defending ourselves from a demagogue and reckoning with our role in having created him? By any historical measure
column19: the Democrats had a pretty great night Tuesday
column20: and the president’s party did not. Donald Trump calls himself a “nationalist.” You needn’t be a racist to believe that national identity and borders matter. Trump makes no pretense of balancing moral imperatives
column21: or even military objectives
column22: against the economic agenda that is his only real priority. The Supreme Court hearings are starting to feel less like the #MeToo movement and more like ruinous politics
column23: Matt Bai says. The fact is that at this elite level of the American judiciary
column24: everybody's smart. But not everybody's good
column25: Matt Bai writes. Trump’s safe choice for the high court has become the last thing he and the GOP needed so close to midterms
column26: Matt Bai writes. Ten years ago last month
column27: I wrote a long cover story for the New York Times Magazine titled: “Is Obama the End of Black Politics?” The central point of the essay
column28: which featured dozens of black leaders and provoked no shortage of debate
column29: was that Barack Obama’s nomination in 2008 marked a turning point Trump’s aides say it’s their duty to protect the president from himself
column30: even if that means stealing papers off his desk.

column1: ---split---10.0---split---https://www.huffpost.com/entry/donald-trump-lawsuit-national-emergency_n_5c65dc88e4b05c889d1d51a7---split---The first lawsuits challenging the legality of President Donald Trump’s national emergency declaration began rolling in on Friday
column2: and lawmakers say more are likely to follow. Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington came out the gate first with a lawsuit alleging that the Department of Justice failed to provide documents concerning the president’s legal authority to invoke emergency powers over a border wall. “Americans deserve to know the true basis for President Trump’s unprecedented decision to enact emergency powers to pay for a border wall
column3: ” CREW Executive Director Noah Bookbinder said in a statement. “We’re suing because the government has so far failed to produce the requested documents or provide an explanation for their delay.” The announcement came the same day Trump confirmed he will use the declaration to divert about $3.6 billion the Defense Department had allocated for construction projects and $2.5 billion earmarked for counterdrug activities in order to fund his long-promised wall on the U.S.-Mexico border ― a project Congress refused to fully fund in the spending bill it passed Thursday. The American Civil Liberties Union announced Friday that it will file a lawsuit early next week arguing that Trump cannot legally use the emergency declaration to evade those funding limits imposed by Congress. “The Constitution assigns Congress the power of the purse
column4: and no prior president has ever tried to use emergency powers to fund a chosen project — particularly a permanent
column5: large-scale domestic project such as this — against congressional will
column6: ” Dror Ladin
column7: staff attorney with the ACLU’s National Security Project
column8: said in a statement. “This is obviously improper.” Other lawsuits are likely to follow. In a press conference on Friday
column9: California Gov. Gavin Newsom (D) and Attorney General Xavier Becerra said they are planning to sue after reviewing the declaration. “Donald Trump
column10: we’ll see you in court
column11: ” the governor said. Becerra said they are “working closely with several other states that feel the same way
column12: ” hinting at a multistate legal effort. Democrats in Congress have also signaled they’re ready to go to court. Soon after Trump’s announcement Friday
column13: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) issued a joint statement
column14: saying
column15: “Congress will defend our constitutional authorities in the Congress
column16: in the Courts
column17: and in the public
column18: using every remedy available.” Plenty of past presidents have declared national emergencies ― something Trump has cited to normalize his plans ― but it’s unprecedented for a president to declare one as a means of bypassing Congress to pay for a project lawmakers won’t endorse. Given the extraordinary nature of Trump’s plan ― not to mention the extraordinary nature of his presidency ― legal scholars have raised concerns that Trump could take advantage of a national emergency declaration and expand its scope far beyond his border wall. In December
column19: the Brennan Center for Justice identified 123 different statutory powers that may become available to Trump in the event he declares a national emergency. Those include letting the federal government seize private vessels at sea
column20: assuming control of internet traffic
column21: deploying the military as a domestic police force and dozens of other actions unrelated to the national emergency he’s claiming. Others have pointed out the dangerous precedent set by a president invoking emergency powers to make good on a campaign promise. “What is particularly troubling here is the idea that the president and administration officials seem to be trying to manufacture an emergency in order to achieve a political goal
column22: ” Brookings Institution legal scholar Margaret Taylor said in a Q&A with Vice News last month Sanjana Karanth contributed reporting. Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? Here’s how.

column1: ---split---10.0---split---https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/15/opinion/munich-trump-europe-iran.html---split---Supported by It's no longer worth pretending Trump is not in the authoritarian camp. The shock has passed. European powers are thinking again. By Roger Cohen Opinion Columnist MUNICH — If the Munich Security Conference had a soul it was embodied in Senator John McCain
column2: always an invigorating presence here and always a fierce advocate of the trans-Atlantic alliance. He’s gone now and so is the idea of inevitable liberal democratic convergence
column3: replaced by great power competition in the age of the strongman. The meeting comes hard on the heels of a strange gathering in Warsaw — yes
column4: Warsaw — convened by the United States and devoted to “Peace and Security in the Middle East.” It might better have been called “Pipe Dreams on the Vistula” or “Trump’s America Bashes Europe.” At the Warsaw conference
column5: Vice President Mike Pence lashed out at Germany
column6: France and Britain for trying “to break American sanctions” against Iran. He seemed as incensed by Europe’s malign behavior as by Iran’s — a curious case of the United States aiding Vladimir Putin’s divisive agenda in Europe. The truth is that the Trump Administration broke the Iran nuclear agreement
column7: undermining America’s word
column8: whose value has declined around the world as sharply as Iran’s rial currency over the last 18 months. Germany
column9: France and Britain believe in the evidence that the nuclear agreement is working
column10: with the Islamic Republic in compliance. The accord was never supposed to transform Iran overnight or sprinkle fairy dust on the Middle East. It was meant to keep Iran from going nuclear. It’s doing that. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo
column11: on a hapless mission to shape Trump’s caprices into policy
column12: declared
column13: “You can’t achieve peace and stability in the Middle East without confronting Iran.” He has this upside down. Peace and stability in the Middle East are impossible without Iran. The Islamic Republic is too big and too influential to shut out. It’s not going anywhere. To say this is not to advocate appeasement. Iran
column14: 40 years after its revolution
column15: is beset by internal contradictions and is predatory abroad. It is to recognize that
column16: as with Europe’s successful Ostpolitik during the Cold War
column17: engagement with a rival power may be the best way to change that power and defuse confrontation. Behind the nuclear deal lay this conviction. It is inscribed in postwar Germany’s DNA. German-American relations are now at a low point. Multilateralism was not just a policy for postwar Germany. It was a core belief. In the construction of a rules-based world order anchored by international organizations
column18: including the European Union and NATO
column19: lay the assurance that history could not repeat itself. Trump has never encountered a multilateralism he does not loathe. The world
column20: for his administration
column21: is a place where rivals “compete for advantage.” The president is for muscular unilateralism in a Hobbesian world — except he hasn’t heard of Hobbes. Global community is pie in the sky; Angela Merkel
column22: the German chancellor
column23: a lost cause. The relationship anchoring the world that the Munich Security Conference sought to buttress has been drained of meaning. This is why Wolfgang Ischinger
column24: the former German ambassador to the United States
column25: wrote in his welcoming remarks of “a reshuffling of core pieces of the international order” and a “leadership vacuum.” Who carries aloft the flag of liberalism and its values with anything resembling the autocratic convictions of the new strongmen — Vladimir Putin in Russia
column26: Xi Jinping in China
column27: Recep Tayyip Erdogan in Turkey
column28: and Donald Trump in the United States? It’s no longer worth pretending that Trump is not in the authoritarian camp. The shock has passed. Europeans have internalized the shift. The best they can offer as liberty’s beacon in America’s stead is Emmanuel Macron
column29: the French president
column30: and Merkel. He is being yellow-vested
column31: and she is in her twilight years. If there is a particular foreboding hanging over this conference
column32: it lies in the fact that the sonderweg
column33: or (loosely) wayward path
column34: of Trump’s America has occurred just as Europe splinters. Brexit is weeks away. Spain has just called yet another election. In France and Germany and Spain
column35: the major political parties are losing power or disintegrating
column36: challenged by nationalist xenophobes
column37: leaving a fragmented political topography. Instability is inevitable. Trump favors such fragmentation because he believes it will leave weaker European powers more susceptible to his winner-takes-all bullying. Europeans have no illusions about this. The old order has frayed to the point of dissolution. It was based on the conviction that words have meaning. For Trump
column38: they do not
column39: as his declaration of a “national emergency” on the southern border with Mexico underscores. Without meaning
column40: no law
column41: no treaty
column42: is worth the paper it’s written on. This is the real danger confronting the West. During the Warsaw theater
column43: Roxana Saberi of CBS News confronted Pompeo on the hypocrisy of the United States denouncing human rights abuses in Iran while embracing Saudi Arabia’s Mohammed bin Salman
column44: who
column45: in the assessment of the C.I.A.
column46: ordered the killing of Jamal Khashoggi
column47: the Washington Post columnist. Pompeo lost it
column48: twice calling Saberi’s legitimate inquiry “a ridiculous question.” European powers see such braggadocio for what it is. They are contemplating the world without its postwar American anchor. Cometh the emergency-declaring strongman. He’s pitched camp in Washington
column49: no less. The Times is committed to publishing a diversity of letters to the editor. We’d like to hear what you think about this or any of our articles. Here are some tips. And here’s our email: letters@nytimes.com. Follow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook

Please read the rules before joining the discussion. For a president to survive in Washington
column3: it helps to have two things: a sense of humor and a dog. Donald Trump is the first Oval Office occupant in decades to have neither. Lara Trump
column4: his daughter-in-law and an animal rescue advocate
column5: has been pressing him to get a rescue dog

column7: Trump made clear there’s probably no puppy in his future. “I don’t have any time
column8: ” he told the audience
column9: adding it “feels a little phony
column10: phony to me.” In fact
column11: a dog’s genuine love
column12: along with a sense of humor
column13: can go a long way toward smoothing over lapses
column14: extinguishing fires and softening unappetizing traits. But the only use Trump seems to have for dogs is as epithets. His critics have been “fired like a dog” and “dumped like a dog.” They choked
column15: cheated
column16: lied
column17: sweated or begged like dogs. Women's March in London on Jan. 19
column18: 2019. (Photo11: Will Oliver/epa-EFE) Read more commentary: During a tragedy a dog may be the only one to bring comfort Repay dogs for their military service. Stop the deadly VA canine experiments. Reader suggestion: Why Donald Trump should get a dog As for a sense of humor
column19: even with a script
column20: a stage and the perfect occasion
column21: Trump can still blow it. He had a shot last March at Washington’s Gridiron Dinner
column22: an annual gathering that brings together journalists and politicians for a mutual roasting. He got off to a strong start. “My staff was concerned heading into this dinner that I couldn’t do self-deprecating humor…. And I told them not to worry. Nobody does self-deprecating humor better than I do.” It was a good line
column23: and the audience was with him. But after several laugh-worthy moments
column24: Trump descended into a long and unfunny stream of consciousness. As for next month’s Gridiron dinner
column25: it’s unclear whether he will attend. A few presidents — John F. Kennedy and Ronald Reagan
column26: in particular — had keen senses of humor that they used to great advantage. (“Please tell me you’re Republicans
column27: ” Reagan famously quipped to surgeons after he was shot in a 1981 assassination attempt.) The last president to have no sense of humor was Richard Nixon. We all know how that story ended. But at least Nixon had dogs. He was often photographed on the beach in San Clemente
column28: the Western White House
column29: with his gorgeous Irish setter King Timahoe. In 1952
column30: his daughters’ cocker spaniel saved his threatened vice-presidential nomination after accusations he took campaign contributions for personal use. Appearing on television to refute the charges
column31: Nixon vowed to keep one personal gift from an admiring voter: a black and white puppy the family named Checkers. ''The kids
column32: like all kids
column33: love the dog
column34: and I just want to say… that regardless of what they say about it
column35: we're going to keep it.” Corny and sentimental
column36: sure. But Nixon emerged from what became known as the Checkers speech with a cleaner reputation. Many other presidents had “celebrity” dogs
column37: too. Warren Harding’s Airedale terrier Laddie Boy had a special chair to sit in during Cabinet meetings. George H.W. and Barbara Bush’s English springer spaniel
column38: Millie
column39: “dictated” a children’s book about her adventures as First Canine. And who could forget Bush’s yellow Labrador service dog
column40: Sully
column41: lying faithfully by the side of his owner’s casket in the Capitol? One of the most famous presidential dogs was Franklin D. Roosevelt’s Scottish terrier
column42: Fala
column43: an inseparable soulmate to FDR
column44: who took him on diplomatic trips. During the 1944 election campaign for Roosevelt’s historic fourth term
column45: Republicans accused him of accidentally leaving Fala behind on a trip and sending a Navy destroyer to pick him up at taxpayers’ expense. At a Teamsters Union speech
column46: Roosevelt replied: “These Republican leaders have not been content with attacks on me
column47: or my wife
column48: or on my sons. No
column49: … they now include my little dog
column50: Fala. Well
column51: of course
column52: I don’t resent attacks … but Fala does resent them.” The Teamsters ate it up
column53: as did a nationwide radio audience — making it a turning point in the campaign. It’s pretty late in the game
column54: but maybe Trump can still discover that a public sense-of-humor would do more for his approval rating than nasty tweets. As for getting a dog
column55: Trump is right
column56: it wouldn’t work if it was just a prop. “How would I look walking a dog on the White House lawn?” he wondered aloud at Monday’s rally. Actually
column57: he might just look more … human. Saundra Torry is a former USA TODAY editorial writer. Follow her on Twitter: @storry1 You can read diverse opinions from our Board of Contributors and other writers on the Opinion front page
column58: on Twitter @usatodayopinion and in our daily Opinion newsletter. To respond to a column

column1: ---split---10.0---split---http://www.rollcall.com/news/opinion/waiting-for-sam-ervin---split---Folksy North Carolina Sen. Sam Ervin
column2: center
column3: chaired the committee that destroyed Nixon’s strongest claim to power — his political popularity
column4: Shapiro writes. (CQ Roll Call file photo) OPINION — It is easy to imagine an undiscovered Samuel Beckett play entitled “Waiting for Mueller.” On stage
column5: faithful Democrats vacillate between stubborn hope (“He should be here”) and fatalistic despair (“He didn’t say for sure that he would come”). In the end
column6: they just wait
column7: day after day. Whatever Robert Mueller’s internal timetable (seers like Rudy Giuliani have so far been comically wrong in trying to predict it)
column8: the investigation will face new pressures with the virtually certain Senate confirmation this week of William Barr. For the first time
column9: Mueller will be supervised by a legitimate attorney general — rather than an acting Donald Trump factotum — who has avoided any promises about releasing the full report. All of this might be ominous for Mueller were it not for existence of Democratic House committee chairmen armed with subpoena power. Jerry Nadler
column10: who chairs the Judiciary Committee
column11: just pointedly announced the appointment of two high-profile Trump critics (Norman Eisen and Barry Berke) as legal consultants. At moments like this
column12: it is tempting to dust off Watergate parallels from the Saturday Night Massacre (Richard Nixon ordered the firing of special prosecutor Archibald Cox) to the House Judiciary impeachment vote that helped precipitate Nixon’s resignation. But there are major differences between Trump’s current troubles and Nixon’s resignation beyond the existence of a presidential Twitter account and capital-letter tweets wailing and railing about a “WITCH HUNT.” Trump’s behavior
column13: from his fan-boy embrace of Vladimir Putin to his cynical profiteering from his hotel empire in the White House
column14: has never been subject to sustained congressional scrutiny. Fired FBI Director James Comey’s June 2017 appearance before the Senate Intelligence Committee remains the most dramatic congressional hearing about Trump’s conduct in the Oval Office. In dramatic contrast
column15: the Senate Watergate Committee hearings
column16: chaired by folksy North Carolina Democrat Sam Ervin
column17: paved the way for Nixon’s downfall. For 51 days from May until November 1973
column18: Americans of all political persuasions were riveted by the Ervin hearings that were broadcast gavel-to-gavel and repeated in the evenings on PBS. According to the Gallup Poll
column19: more than 70 percent of Americans watched at least part of the hearings. Watch: How does impeachment work? The hearings had everything
column20: including the stunning revelation by Nixon aide Alexander Butterfield that the president had a taping system for recording conversations in the Oval Office. The parade of witnesses included comic characters like tough-talking retired New York City detective Tony Ulasewicz
column21: who recounted his adventures as a Nixon bagman delivering cash payoffs to the plotters behind the Watergate break-in. But the hearings were mostly defined by gravely serious witnesses like former White House counsel John Dean
column22: who testified about telling Nixon
column23: “There was a cancer growing on the presidency and that if the cancer was not removed
column24: then the president himself would be killed by it.” (I should mention that the idea for this column was triggered by a recent conversation with Taylor Branch
column25: the Pulitzer Prize-winning Martin Luther King biographer. More relevant
column26: Branch was the ghostwriter for Dean’s bestselling Watergate confessional
column27: “Blind Ambition.”) The Ervin committee hearings destroyed Nixon’s strongest claim to power — his political popularity. At the beginning of 1973
column28: fresh off his 49-state sweep against George McGovern
column29: Nixon boasted a lofty approval rating of 68 percent. By August 1973
column30: Nixon had lost more than half his supporters
column31: with the Gallup Poll clocking him in at a dismal 31 percent. Although Nixon survived in the White House for another year
column32: his approval rating never again came close to 40 percent. Despite a mostly buoyant economy
column33: Trump’s own approval rating has been bouncing along for months just over 40 percent. But for all the attention devoted to the Mueller investigation in Washington
column34: there remains a level of abstraction surrounding it. It’s like a battle scene in Shakespeare when everything is occurring offstage — and the audience just gets periodic bulletins from messengers and wounded soldiers. While nothing is certain
column35: the odds seem high that Trump’s popularity would take a major hit if Americans got to view protracted public testimony from the likes of Michael Cohen
column36: Roger Stone
column37: Paul Manafort
column38: Michael Flynn and
column39: yes
column40: Jared Kushner. Whether the topic were plans for the Trump Tower in Moscow or campaign payoffs to the president’s purported paramours
column41: it would be hard for honest Republicans to dismiss such a tawdry parade of Trump associates as “fake news.” But a dramatic set of congressional hearings needs more than just a compelling roster of witnesses. Part of the secret of the success of the Ervin committee was that
column42: as a select Senate body
column43: it was limited to just seven hand-picked members. As a result
column44: senators could pursue their inquiries without being tongue-tied by arbitrary time limits. Nadler’s Judiciary Committee
column45: in contrast
column46: has (gulp) 41 members. Unless committee Democrats are willing to subordinate their political egos for a larger cause
column47: there would be no way to follow a consistent line of inquiry in the face of expected GOP obstruction. Maybe the solution would be for Nancy Pelosi to appoint a small select committee on the Watergate model. Or maybe the bulk of the questioning before the Judiciary and similar committees should be handled by senior staffers and outside attorneys rather than individual legislators preening during their five minutes on camera. All predictions about Trump’s future have to be balanced against the reality that House Democrats are planning what they hope will be the most explosive set of congressional hearings in nearly half a century. These hearings may prove as politically important as the Mueller report itself. Which is why there may be still another Beckett play called “Waiting for Nadler.” Walter Shapiro has covered the last 10 presidential campaigns. He is also a fellow at the Brennan Center for Justice at NYU and a lecturer in political science at Yale. Follow him on Twitter @MrWalterShapiro. column2: during which President Donald Trump declared a national emergency in order to secure up to $8 billion in funding for a border wall

column4: President Trump repeatedly called into question and even dismissed as lies much of the available data that exists on immigration and crime
column5: all while glorifying countries like China that give drug dealers the death penalty and painting a picture of a country under siege by criminal invaders. So
column6: Karem asked
column7: what is that picture based on? President Trump responded in generalities. “I get my numbers from a lot of sources
column8: like Homeland Security
column9: primarily. The numbers I have from Homeland Security are a disaster
column10: ” he said. Asked to clarify what numbers he’s referring to
column11: Trump said
column12: “I use many stats.” https://twitter.com/WIRED/status/1096478979178008576 One possible reason President Trump may have had trouble producing those stats? They don’t really exist. Again and again throughout his remarks
column13: and throughout his years-long battle to build a wall on the southern border
column14: President Trump has relied
column15: instead
column16: on anecdotes
column17: highlighting
column18: for example
column19: the heartbreaking stories of mothers whose children have been killed by undocumented immigrants or noting

column21: individual examples of people being killed on the border last week. These stories confirm President Trump’s stated belief that something new and dangerous is taking place on the border
column22: and so he holds up them up as all the proof the American public needs that he's right. But as the saying goes
column23: the plural of anecdote is not data. The government's own data
column24: instead
column25: suggest just the opposite of what the president needs the country to believe in order to fulfill his chief campaign promise and build a border wall. “His speech basically repeated every falsehood
column26: every misconception
column27: and every untruth that has been stated about the border and illegal immigrant crime and national security threats involving immigration for the last several years
column28: ” says Alex Nowrasteh
column29: a senior immigration policy analyst at libertarian think tank Cato Institute. Take the president’s suggestion on Friday that a disproportionately high number of undocumented people make up the federal prison population. According to a Department of Justice report released last June
column30: about 20 percent of the federal prison population in the first quarter of 2018 were “known or suspected aliens
column31: ” and 93 percent of them were in the country illegally. The Federal Bureau of Prisons told WIRED on Friday that "19.3 percent of the BOP's inmates have either unknown or non-US citizenship
column32: which, of course, includes a far broader category of immigrants than only the undocumented ones. But the demographics of the federal prison population are hardly a fair proxy for the country as a whole. As the DOJ’s report states, 90 percent of the incarcerated population in the US resides in state and local prisons, and the rate of undocumented people in state and local prisons is far harder to calculate, as few states report those statistics. In Texas, one state that does calculate these figures, a Cato report found that in 2015, as a percentage of their respective populations
column33: there were 50 percent fewer criminal convictions of illegal immigrants than of native-born Americans." In addition
column34: immigration offenses are themselves federal offenses. It stands to reason
column35: then
column36: that people serving time for immigration offenses would be overrepresented in the prisons where people serve time for immigration offenses. The DOJ report doesn’t state what percentage of undocumented immigrants are in federal prison for violence or drug charges. Neither did President Trump. Then there’s the president’s insistence that Democrats are lying when they say ports of entry
column37: and not the southern border
column38: are most responsible for drug smuggling. But in November of 2018
column39: the Drug Enforcement Administration reported exactly that. “The most common method employed by these [transnational criminal organizations] involves transporting illicit drugs through U.S. [ports of entry] in passenger vehicles with concealed compartments or commingled with legitimate goods on tractor trailers
column40: ” the report reads. The president's bleak description of rampant violence along the border also stands in stark contrast to what the Federal Bureau of Investigation's statistics show
column41: Nowrasteh says. According to FBI crime reports obtained by Cato
column43: the violent crime rate
column44: property crime rate
column45: and homicide rate were lower along border counties than they were in the United States writ large. Not only that
column46: but according to Customs and Border Patrol
column47: in 2018 gang members accounted for just .2 percent of all apprehensions at the border. "Those numbers would be very different if there was a real invasion
column48: Nowrasteh says. Such willful distorting of data in the service of stoking fear about a group of people has scary historical precedents, says Jason Stanley, a philosophy professor at Yale University and author of the book How Fascism Works. He's saying data doesn't matter. He’s saying
column49: 'This is about my power
column50: '" Stanley says. "It’s a sign of power that you can declare a national emergency without there being one." Before President Trump even completed his address
column51: he anticipated the ways in which that power may be checked. "We will have a national emergency
column52: and we’ll then be sued
column53: he said, expressing full confidence that the Supreme Court would eventually uphold his declaration. Hours later, the American Civil Liberties Union announced its plans to file a lawsuit early next week, arguing that the president's actions are unprecedented." “By the president’s very own admission in the Rose Garden
column54: there is no national emergency. He just grew impatient and frustrated with Congress
column55: and decided to move along his promise for a border wall ‘faster
column56: '" the ACLU's staff attorney
column57: Dror Ladin
column58: wrote in a statement. "This is a patently illegal power grab that hurts American communities and flouts the checks and balances that are hallmarks of our democracy." The data may not matter to the White House. Now we'll see if it matters to the courts. Immigrants founded half of the billion dollar startups in the US. column1: ---split---11.0---split---https://www.nbcnews.com/think/opinion/trump-s-emergency-declaration-build-wall-will-cost-americans-more-ncna972146---split---There is a national emergency
column2: but it’s not coming from caravans massing in Mexico. It’s from an authoritarian flailing in Washington. The crisis that the country is now confronting has less to do with a porous physical boundary than with how the limits of presidential power are eroding before our eyes. President Donald Trump has ended weeks of flirting with the use of emergency powers to build his border wall and is taking the plunge. But one can only ruminate on an “emergency” for months before a solution is proffered that will take a decade to implement when the emergency is flimflam – a tissue of an excuse to assume ordinarily unavailable powers. The situation on the border is hardly an emergency. Unauthorized border crossings are lower than they’ve been in almost a half-century: Barely 300
column3: 000 people were detained trying to cross in fiscal year 2017
column4: when the border was more secure than ever
column5: as compared with 1.6 million in FY2000. The percentage of undocumented immigrants in border states is falling. And the counties abutting the Mexican border are among the nation’s safest. There are humanitarian challenges at the border
column6: but Trump and his inhumane policies are largely their cause rather than solution. Tellingly Trump seems to have culled his most colorful warnings of border-related dangers from the silver screen and even admitted that his proclamation is a farce: “I didn’t need to do this
column7: but I’d rather do it much faster
column8: ” he said in his bizarre Friday press conference. But if something isn’t even necessary
column9: it’s definitely not an emergency. The crisis to which Trump is actually responding relates to his own impotence: The self-styled master negotiator couldn’t persuade even quiescent Republicans to fund a wall during their congressional supremacy and then he couldn’t leverage his government shutdown to force one from a Democratic majority. So he’s decided to cut Congress out of the policy-making process. Doing so will unleash legal and political firestorms. Congress will vote on a resolution to end the “emergency
column10: ” forcing Trump to veto it if passed. And it will trigger lawsuits not only from legislators upset that he’s seizing their constitutional prerogatives
column11: but from border-area landowners unwilling to sacrifice their property on the altar of King Donald’s whims now freed
column12: as a result of the president’ emergency order
column13: from the restrictions of the Depression-era Declaration of Takings Act which would otherwise limit their ability to sue to stop the project. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell had warned against such a declaration before essentially agreeing to it; Republicans are already worried about the precedent a non-emergency emergency declaration sets. “I don’t believe that’s the way we should be doing these sorts of things
column14: ” said Florida GOP Sen. Marco Rubio
column15: who had previously mused that a future Democratic president might use such a declaration about climate change to seize fossil-fuel power plants. (Indeed
column16: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Thursday noted that the next Democratic president might declare gun violence a national emergency.) But forget a future Democrat’s intentions: If Trump
column17: long on despotic instincts and short on patience
column18: gets away with this declaration
column19: why wouldn’t he do it again? It’s staggering to imagine what other dead-end fancies might he resurrect as emergencies. On the precedent question
column20: though
column21: it will be instructive to see how quickly the 2020 Democratic hopefuls’ condemnations of Trump’s overreach will be replaced with vows to exercise emergency powers to deal with issues such as climate change
column22: gun violence or health care in the absence of Congressional action. But even if that doesn’t happen this election cycle
column23: if Trump’s power-grab isn’t slapped down — hard — it’s inevitable that unfettered emergency declaration powers will become stump speech and debate staples before becoming staples of presidential legislating. Accomplishing something in the face of partisan sclerosis does have a certain appeal in 2019. But
column24: as Julius Caesar is credited with saying
column25: “All bad precedents begin as justifiable measures.” (Caesar
column26: remember
column27: had first-hand experience with a necrotic republic.) Our system was designed around checks
column28: balances and the need for compromise. Power was divided among three co-equal branches of government
column29: each able to check the power of the others. Congress makes laws — including ones dictating how the federal government raises and spends money — and the president executes them faithfully. This is basic high school civics stuff
column30: which might explain why it seems mysterious to Trump. His national emergency scheme threatens to upend that balance. If emergency declarations become a way for an executive to legislate
column31: then a president unable or unwilling to reach a deal with Congress need not make the effort to engage with the constitutional requirements set forth by our Founding Fathers. And to the extent that members of Congress go along with this — and several seem poised to join Sen. Lindsey Graham
column32: R-S.C.
column33: in the quisling caucus — they are deliberately downgrading their branch from coequal to subordinate
column34: and slouching toward irrelevant. This is just the latest and arguably most dangerous instance of a trend that predates Trump but which
column35: like everything else he touches
column36: he’s made worse. Over recent decades the unwritten rules of politics
column37: norms which distinguished powers that could be exercised from ones that should be
column38: have increasingly been disregarded. So the filibuster
column39: once rarely used
column40: is now the Senate standard. Acts of political terrorism – threatening deliberate harm to Americans through a government shutdown or national debt default unless otherwise unachievable demands are met – have become commonplace. Prosecutorial discretion was a matter of efficiency before President Barack Obama made it a policy tool. The Senate accepted a president’s power to fill Supreme Court vacancies during his term until
column41: without precedent
column42: it didn’t. McConnell’s threat to politicize the response to 2016 Russian hacking scuttled the idea of politics stopping at the shoreline. And national emergencies were heretofore used to enact noncontroversial responses to real crises rather than as a tool of expediency for politically untenable ends. In each case
column43: politicians maximized partisan gains with little regard for long-term consequences. It’s a political tragedy of the commons
column44: where the desire to score points subsumes the greater good of having a functional and responsive political system. All of those examples illustrate a broader
column45: darker picture of a political culture finding short-cuts away from the sometimes-arduous process of consensus
column46: compromise and cooperation and instead opting for the quicker and easier — but constitutionally destructive — path of authoritarianism facilitated by obstruction. When running for office
column47: Donald Trump promised repeatedly that Mexico was going to pay for his wall. Instead
column48: it turns out
column49: that we all may pay for it – both with our taxes and with our polity. Robert Schlesinger is a veteran Washington journalist and commentator. He is the author of “White House Ghosts: Presidents and Their Speechwriters.” © 2019 NBC UNIVERSAL

column1: ---split---11.0---split---https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/15/us/politics/emergency-border-wall.html---split---Supported by By Michael Tackett WASHINGTON — President Trump has decided to roll out the big cannon. In the Rose Garden on Friday
column2: he said he was declaring a national emergency to build a wall on the border with Mexico
column3: using money from other federal accounts
column4: after Congress declined to authorize sufficient funds to satisfy him in legislation that averts another government shutdown. Mr. Trump is wielding extraordinary power to get his way. Democrats strenuously dispute that there is a national security crisis on the border that warrants using the kind of presidential authority that in the past has been used for grave matters like the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Here are six takeaways from Mr. Trump’s action. Republicans in Congress
column5: including Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky
column6: the majority leader
column7: were fine with the spending deal that they reached with Democrats to keep the government open. But more hard-line elements within the party scalded Mr. Trump with criticism
column8: including the Fox host Laura Ingraham and the conservative commentator Ann Coulter. But as The New York Times reported early Friday
column9: the president felt cornered into accepting the deal and agreed to it only with Mr. McConnell’s promise to support an emergency declaration. Still
column10: the White House assuaged some other skeptics of the funding deal
column11: namely Sean Hannity on Fox and the radio host Rush Limbaugh
column12: both of whom in effect announced the president’s decision in advance and encouraged their followers to fall in line. Mr. Trump is willing to risk the blowback
column13: even from members of his party
column14: and a possible court defeat
column15: if it means he can tell his core supporters that he did all he could to build the wall. Democrats cannot stop the president from issuing the declaration
column16: but they can make it very uncomfortable for Republicans. They can vote to terminate the president’s declaration on the grounds that there is no emergency — there is strong sentiment among Democrats to do that — which would force Republicans in the Senate to make a tough vote over Mr. Trump’s extraordinary exercise of power. Already
column17: Senator Susan Collins
column18: Republican of Maine
column19: has been sharply critical of the president using his authority this way
column20: and fellow Republican Senators Marco Rubio of Florida and Rand Paul of Kentucky also have been highly skeptical. Mr. Paul called it “extraconstitutional.” So the president’s action will force Republicans to decide whether to back him — and then set a precedent for a future Democratic president to use power this way — or embarrass Mr. Trump with a vote that could undo his declaration. The president could veto the resolution
column21: and the declaration would likely remain in place because there would not be sufficient votes to override it
column22: but his standing would be undermined. Mr. Trump has to find money from other federal programs to make up a $4 billion shortfall from his initial demand for border wall funding. He can do this by taking money from funding for projects. The declaration enables Mr. Trump to divert $3.6 billion budgeted for military construction projects
column23: and he will also tap into $2.5 billion from counternarcotics programs and $600 million from a Treasury Department asset forfeiture fund. All told
column24: that leaves him with about $8 billion for the wall
column25: including the $1.375 billion authorized by Congress in the spending package that averts a government shutdown. Each of those pots of money comes with a specific constituency that authorized it in the first place
column26: and those constituencies may not be pleased to see it used for another purpose. With this declaration
column27: a court challenge is a near certainty. A party opposing the president will probably seek an injunction — a halt in the action — while the matter is litigated. Yet every day that the wall is not built could undermine Mr. Trump’s fundamental premise that there is an emergency at the border. The challenges are likely to be many
column28: in jurisdictions from coast to coast
column29: increasing the chances that new construction would not start any time soon. Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California has been among the few Democrats who seem to be able to stare down the president. In this case
column30: she has offered a not-so-subtle warning about what she sees as an abuse of the emergency authority. She pointed to the mass shootings in the United States
column31: and noted that perhaps the president should issue a national emergency about guns. That could be a mere preview of how she and the Democrats will frame the case against the president
column32: starting with the idea that he has abused is constitutional authority. After his speech on Friday
column33: Ms. Pelosi and Senator Chuck Schumer of New York
column34: the Democratic leader
column35: vowed to try to overturn the decision. “This is plainly a power grab by a disappointed president
column36: who has gone outside the bounds of the law to try to get what he failed to achieve in the constitutional legislative process
column37: ” they said in a joint statement. Expect to hear a lot from Ms. Pelosi about a basic tenet of American government
column38: that Congress is a coequal branch of government that is not cowed by presidential whim. Democratic presidential candidates already believe they have a list of reasons to deny Mr. Trump a second term. In turn
column39: he has increasingly tried to cast them as far-left socialists. The national emergency declaration may give Democrats an opening to turn his case upside-down
column40: allowing them to argue that he has governed as an authoritarian who put his desires for a pet project above democracy.    Advertisement

Critics have noted that border crossings are down significantly from a decade ago and that most illegal drugs coming through the border arrive through ports of entry. How both sides frame the situation at the border will play a central role in the legal battles that will follow Trump's national emergency declaration. Democrats have accused Trump of manufacturing the crisis to build political support for the wall. Apprehensions along the southern border are actually at historic lows. Many of the migrants arriving in the caravans are applying for asylum

column12: BBC North America editor The trouble with going nuclear is there is fall-out. This has been presented as a predictably partisan issue. On one side of the wall
column13: Republicans; on the other side Democrats. But by going nuclear the president has made it more complicated than that. There are a lot of Republicans - in the Senate and in the House - deeply uneasy about what Mr Trump is doing. Why? Because the constitutional arrangement of the US is that Congress - not the president - controls the purse strings and allocates funds. This is a major land grab by the president. It undermines their position and sets a very dangerous precedent. House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Democrat leader Chuck Schumer responded to Mr Trump's announcement with a statement saying they would challenge the move in Congress and in the courts "using every remedy available". "The president's unlawful declaration over a crisis that does not exist does great violence to our Constitution and makes America less safe

---split---12.0---split---https://www.huffpost.com/entry/climate-change-resolution-national-emergency_n_5c670757e4b01757c36b6b0a---split---Rep. Earl Blumenauer (D-Ore.) swung back at President Donald Trump’s declaration of a national emergency on Friday over a border wall by announcing plans to introduce a similar resolution for a crisis that scientists around the world warn we are running out of time to address ― climate change. “If Trump can call a national emergency for a fake crisis at the border, then surely Congress should call a national emergency for a REAL crisis,” Blumenauer said in a statement. During a press conference on Friday, Trump admitted that the situation along the U.S.-Mexico border did not warrant such a declaration. “I didn’t need to do this, but I’d rather do it much faster,” he said. In a related letter to congressional colleagues, Blumenauer called Trump’s decision “profoundly disturbing” and urged them to join him in co-sponsoring his emergency resolution on climate change. “What our country should be doing right now is focusing on addressing a real national emergency and one of the most pressing issues of our time: the climate crisis,” Blumenauer wrote. “If Donald Trump wants to start declaring national emergencies for fake crises, Congress should address the real ones, starting with climate change.” With his controversial decision, Trump may have opened the door to a broader use of emergency declarations. “We should do something about the actual emergencies that plague our nation — like climate change or health care access — not playing politics in order to build a wasteful border wall,” Sen. Kamala Harris (Calif.), one of several Democratic presidential candidates, tweeted on Friday. We should do something about the actual emergencies that plague our nation — like climate change or health care access — not playing politics in order to build a wasteful border wall. Rep. Ilhan Omar (D-Minn.) called on America’s next president to take that kind of step. Our next President should declare a #NationalEmergency on day 1 to address the existential threat to all life on the planet posed by Climate Change. And Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) warned that Trump’s use of emergency powers could lead to a Democratic president declaring an emergency to combat gun violence and then instituting universal background checks and banning assault weapons. 100 people die from guns every day. That’s a national emergency. If Trump gets away w this border emergency declaration, then a Dem President can declare a gun violence emergency and institute universal background checks and an assault weapons ban by executive action. So... In a January post on the Legal Planet blog, Dan Farber, a law professor at the University of California, Berkeley, explored a number of ways that future presidents could use emergency powers to fight climate change. Doing so, Farber wrote, “would be far more legitimate than Trump’s wall effort,” given the scientific community’s warnings and the fact that the Pentagon has recognized that climate change is a national security threat. Late last year, the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change and scientists from more than a dozen federal agencies in the U.S. issued separate reports concluding that averting climate catastrophe would require immediate, sweeping cuts in global greenhouse gas emissions. Still, the Trump administration has downplayed the threat. “I don’t believe it,” Trump said of his own administration’s report, adding that “we’re the cleanest we’ve ever been.” Blumenauer is one of dozens of co-sponsors of the Green New Deal, a nonbinding climate resolution introduced last week by Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) and Sen. Ed Markey (D-Mass.). The measure outlines the lofty goals of slashing global greenhouse gas emissions 40 to 60 percent by 2030, building climate-resilient infrastructure, and reversing income inequality by creating high-wage green jobs. Republicans were quick to dismiss it as an “impossible” and “pie-in-the-sky” proposal, and Trump said it “sounds like a high school term paper that got a low mark.” “The climate crisis is impacting our world as we know it,” Blumenauer said Friday. “Every day, our temperatures are rising and our sea levels are following suit, threatening more intense storms and natural disasters. Saving the planet is our most pressing issue that must be addressed with urgent action, not a manufactured ‘crisis’ at the border.” Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? Here’s how.

---split---12.0---split---https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/15/us/politics/fact-checking-trump-emergency-border.html---split---Supported by Fact Check To justify redirecting federal funds to a wall, the president made a litany of assertions about crime, drugs and other issues on the southern border. Nearly all were misleading, exaggerated or false. By Linda Qiu As President Trump declared a national emergency on Friday to bypass Congress and build his long-promised wall, he again painted a portrait of a lawless, chaotic border and cited arguments about the effectiveness of the kind of barrier he has in mind that were not rooted in facts. Illegal border crossings have been declining for decades. While families are overwhelming an immigration system devised to handle single men, a border wall would not prevent them from seeking asylum, which is legal. Research does not show that immigrants commit more crimes than native-born Americans. And a wall would do little to prevent drugs and human trafficking at the border, as official ports of entry are the main route into the United States for both. Cumulatively, Mr. Trump’s unsupported or misleading statements undercut his rationale for declaring an emergency, a step that is widely viewed as testing both constitutional and political norms and is sure to draw legal challenges. What Was Said “In El Paso they have close to 2,000 murders right on the other side of the wall. And they had 23 murders. It’s a lot of murders. But it’s not close to 2,000 murders right on the other side of the wall in Mexico.” Mr. Trump is correct that there were 23 murders in El Paso last year, compared with more than 1,200 murders in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico. But the disparity predates the existence of border barriers separating the two towns. In 2007, the year before border fencing construction began, El Paso reported 17 murders while Juárez recorded about 320 homicides, before the drug war between cartels escalated. In 2010, after the barriers were largely completed, El Paso recorded five murders before the number increased to 16 a year later. That same year, murders in Juárez topped 3,600 before declining to over 2,000 in 2011. What Was Said “When you look and when you listen to politicians — in particular, certain Democrats — they say it all comes through the port of entry. It’s wrong. It’s wrong. It’s just a lie. It’s all a lie.” Mr. Trump was referring to the flow of drugs across the border and disputing arguments that most smuggling takes place not in remote areas where a wall might be built but through authorized border crossing points, or ports of entry. The relevant statistics come from Mr. Trump’s own agencies, not Democrats. Data from Customs and Border Protection shows that 80 percent to 90 percent of heroin, cocaine, methamphetamine and fentanyl is seized at ports of entry (marijuana is the exception). The Drug Enforcement Administration noted that a “small percentage of all heroin” is seized at areas between ports of entry. What Was Said “You can’t take human traffic — women and girls — you can’t take them through ports of entry.” You can. For example, the Justice Department recently detailed how an international sex trafficking ring committed visa fraud to transport women from Thailand into the United States and coerce them into the sex trade. About 80 percent of human trafficking victims passed through official ports of entry, according to a decade’s worth of data collected by the Counter-Trafficking Data Collaborative. The Polaris Project, a group that works to prevent human trafficking in the United States, said in a statement that out of nearly 50,000 cases it has handled, “the vast majority of victims” arrive through ports of entry. What Was Said “Take a look at Israel. They’re building another wall. Their wall is 99.9 percent effective, they told me — 99.9 percent.” Israel built a wall along its border with Egypt in 2013, and it has proved to be effective. Israeli officials have said that illegal crossings decreased to 12 in 2014 from more than 16,000 in 2011 — a 99 percent reduction. Whether that example could be applied to the United States is another matter, as PolitiFact has reported. The border between Israel and Egypt is much shorter than the United States-Mexico border, along flat land as opposed to mountainous terrain. Israel also invested in technology and manpower to guard its border. What Was Said “And the people that say we create precedent, well, what do you have 56 or a lot of times that is creating precedent.” Mr. Trump is right that previous presidents have issued 58 national emergency declarations since 1978, 30 of which are still in effect. But those declarations have largely dealt with crises and conflicts abroad. Examples include blocking transactions with the Taliban, prohibiting the importation of diamonds from Sierra Leone, placing restrictions on North Korea and allowing faster treatment during the swine flu outbreak in 2009. Mr. Trump’s declaration, however, is extraordinary in that it addresses a domestic policy issue and involves redirecting money without the approval of Congress. What Was Said “I went through Congress. I made a deal. I got almost $1.4 billion when I wasn’t supposed to get $1, not $1, he’s not going to get $1. Well, I got $1.4 billion, but I’m not happy with it.” The funding deal passed by Congress on Thursday authorized $1.375 billion for border fencing, which is less than the $1.6 billion that senators proposed last June and that Mr. Trump rejected. Asked about his reaction to the reduced funding, Mr. Trump misleadingly cited comments made by Speaker Nancy Pelosi. At a news conference in January, while the government was still partially shut down, Ms. Pelosi jokingly said that she would agree to give Mr. Trump $1 for his border wall. But Ms. Pelosi and Democrats have consistently drawn a distinction between the wall and border security, referring to employing technology enhancements and additional personnel as well as barriers. At that same January news conference, Ms. Pelosi and other Democrats promoted a bill that included $1.3 billion for border fencing and would have temporarily reopened the government. Other claims: Mr. Trump also repeated four other claims about immigration and his border wall that The New York Times has previously fact-checked: He misleadingly claimed that he had already “done a lot of wall.” (The first extension of barriers built before Mr. Trump took office, 14 miles, is scheduled to begin this month — a tiny portion of the 1,000-mile wall he promised.) He falsely claimed that the money for the wall was coming from the revised North American Free Trade Agreement. (Any additional federal revenue from the trade deal, which is not guaranteed, would still be coming from American consumers, not Mexico.) He claimed, with no evidence, that the man charged in a Manhattan truck attack sponsored “22 or 23 or 35 of his family members” to immigrate to the United States. (This is not possible, as the man was a green-card holder who would not have been able to sponsor extended family.) He claimed, with no evidence, that other countries are “putting some very bad people” in the diversity visa lottery. (Individuals enter the lottery on their own, and must pass a screening process that bars criminals and the indigent.) Curious about the accuracy of a claim? Email factcheck@nytimes.com. Linda Qiu is a fact-check reporter, based in Washington. She came to The Times in 2017 from the fact-checking service PolitiFact. @ylindaqiu Advertisement
